Can the minister also confirm that last weekend representatives of Manildra attended a National Party fundraiser on the Mid North Coast of New South Wales and generously bid $1,000 for a bottle of Rosemount signed by the Deputy Prime Minister and $5,000 for a bottle of Grange signed by the Prime Minister, among other items? Is there any connection between Manildra's financial largesse to the coalition and the coalition's largesse to Manildra through production subsidies for a near monopoly activity, which, Minister, you tell me was worth $17,132,670.09 between 17 October last year and 30 May this year?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âBeing a member of the Liberal Party and not the National Party I am not in any position to confirm which business observers attended the New South Wales National Party conference last weekend, or whenever it was. But for the Labor Party to have the hide to reflect adversely and dishonourably upon the Manildra Group and, indeed, the government in relation to any donations that it may makeâand, as I have read, the head of Manildra supports both political partiesâis quite outrageous in light of the rort that goes on in sustaining the Labor Party through Centenary House and the outrageous lease arrangements which they have. How dare they come in here and make any suggestions of impropriety on our part.

âOrder! I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Republic of Croatia led by the Speaker, His Excellency Mr Zlatko Tomcic. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

âIn his budget speech delivered on 13 May, the Treasurer announced further tax cuts to Australian workers and families. My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Coonan. Can the minister advise the Senate of the progress of delivering these tax cuts to Australian workers and families? Further, is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âSenator Tchen, thank you for the question. It is with great pleasure that I am able to inform the Senate that last night the government's $2.4 billion tax cut was passed and will come into effect on 1 July. The fact is that these tax cuts really are l-a-wâthey actually exist and they will be delivered. They are evidence of the Howard government's philosophy that once vital expenditure needs are metâdefence, national security, health and higher education reformâmoney should be returned to taxpayers.

answer.para: The tax cut is also progressive. The biggest percentage benefit goes to low-income earners, particularly those who benefit from the increase in the low-income tax offset. The tax cut adds to the $12 billion in the personal income tax cuts that were a central part of the government's tax reform package in 2000-01. They were the largest tax cuts in Australian history. There can be no room for doubt about this government's commitment to tax reform. The Howard government has also abolished the wholesale sales tax, abolished financial institutions duty, abolished stamp duty on share transfers, halved capital gains tax, introduced family tax benefits parts A and B, reduced company tax from 36 per cent to 30 per cent, introduced the baby bonus, abolished Labor's automatic indexation of fuel excise, cut effective diesel excise rates for heavy vehicles and introduced the private health insurance rebate.

Meanwhile, Labor is missing in action on the issue of tax. On the one hand, they claim that the tax cut is too small and that they will further reduce the overall tax burden. However, so far they have promised to fund their promises by opposing or reversing the government's tax cuts. Labor are committed to opposing our international tax reforms which will make Australia more competitive as a regional centre. Just earlier today the opposition refused to pass reforms to the tax treatment of workers who are temporarily resident in Australia. Who does this hurt? It hurts Australian employers who usually bear the cost of bringing nurses, engineers, occupational therapists and other professionals to Australia to fill jobs where there are identified shortages. The Labor Party oppose our reduction in the superannuation surcharge. They want to abolish the baby bonus. They still have not come clean on what they are going to do about the private health insurance rebateâand whatever commitments they give only last about as long as the appointment and tenure of each successive shadow health minister. And of course we all know that Labor have form when it comes to abolishing tax cuts. Who can ever forget the disappearing l-a-w tax cuts after the 1993 election?

If ever we needed more evidence that Labor cannot be trusted on tax we need look no further than the Labor state governments. In Victoria the Bracks government has increased car registration and indexed hundreds of fees and fines to the CPI. In South Australia the Rann government has slugged every household $30 a year. In Western Australia the Gallop government has increased stamp duty on property transfers. In Queensland the Beattie government has introduced a new $88 tax on all electricity account holders.

We have Labor's promises to oppose or reverse at least three key tax cuts of the government. Whoever leads the Labor Party, they are and always will be a party of higher taxes on hardworking Australian families. When it comes to Labor promises, don't listen to what Labor says, watch what Labor does. Labor stands for higher taxes. The only party with any commitment to removing the tax burden from ordinary Australians is the government.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of distinguished former senator the Rev. John Woodley. Welcome back, John. Nothing has changed much since you left. It is good to see you here.

âMy question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Vanstone. Can the minister confirm that, on current estimates, 651,000 families will receive family debts averaging $851 as a result of incorrect family payments made last financial yearâno fewer debts than the previous financial year despite her claims that, as families became accustomed to the system, debts would drop? Why has the minister's department now advised the Prime Minister that overpayments will fall this year by approximately 200,000 as a result of the so-called more choices package when just 77,000 families have in fact taken up the package? When is the minister going to admit that her family payments system is fundamentally flawed?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for the opportunity given to me by his question to yet again point out the tremendous increase in payments to families by this government. The amount we spend now is something like $11 billion a year in support for families, something the previous government never did. I pointed out in my answer to a question yesterday what a substantial increase in support to families there has been under this government. There has been a change and, three years later, we still have the Labor Party asking about it because they still have not cottoned on.

answer.para: The change is to an annual payment to families, where families in one set of circumstances, with the same income and the same number of children of the same age, will get the same amount of money. If Labor wants to market itself as a party of equity treatment, it will support a system where families in the same position with the same income get the same assistance. This system will allow for an advance payment of that annual payment, to be paid out fortnightly, based on a customer's estimate of income. Just as with the tax system, where some people get a refund cheque and some people get a letter saying, `You owe us more,' so it is with the family tax benefit system. Some people will have underestimated their income and because they have actually earned more than that they will obviously get less support, because under this system the richer people get less and the poorer people get more. They would therefore need to pay some money back.

I did not hear the good senator refer in his question to the hundreds of thousands of families who overestimate their income, find out they have earned less at the end of the year and, under this system, get a top-up in a way that they never did in the past. Hundreds of thousands of families are getting a top-up. We regard a system, Senatorâthrough you, Mr Presidentâwhere families in the same circumstances with the same income get the same amount of money as a fair and equitable system. We do not regard it as flawed; we regard it as a fair and equitable system.

It is a massive change from the way things used to be, Senator, with a complicated range of payments now down to two or three much simpler payments. It is a change whereby entitlement is not based on your position on a fortnightly basis but on an annual basis. It is aligned with the tax system. As long as this system stays in place, just as with the tax system, there will be people at the end of the year who get a top-up and there will be people at the end of the year who have an overpayment and who will probably either pay that back directly, if they can afford to, or will treat it as a down-payment on next year's very generous payments. I remind you, Senator, that the average payment to a family is over $5,000 tax free. I recall that members opposite raised in this chamber the case of a man on an income of around $30,000 who has seven children. He gets something like $25,000 tax free under this system. It is a very fair system and a very generous system, clouded for the public, I might say, by misconceptions carried into the community by Labor.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister explain why the average level of family payment debts has risen by around $20 since the first year in which the system operated? Why is the minister's department refusing to consider any changes to family payment rules when the number of families in debt has not dropped and the amount of debt each family owes is rising each year?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI note that the senator still refers to these as debtsâin one sense they are; it is money that has to be paid backâbut that terminology of course conceals that a family in the same set of circumstances as the family next door has more money than the family next door. I do not think that is equitable. If you are in the same set of circumstances as the family next doorâwith the same income and with the same number of kids of the same agesâyou should get the same amount of money. And if you have received more money, you should pay it back.

âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing, Senator Kay Patterson. Will the minister outline to the Senate how the Howard government's A Fairer Medicare package addresses the need to assist GPs to bulk-bill while remaining fiscally responsible? Is the minister aware of any alternative unfunded proposals for Medicare that will increase the financial burden on Australian families?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Eggleston and acknowledge his interest in health and his significant background as a medical practitioner. The $917 million fully funded package of measures is to strengthen Medicare to make it more accessible and more affordable. The Labor Party never cared a skerrick about accessibility. They refused to address the issue. There were too few doctors in rural areas and too few doctors in outer metropolitan areas; the doctors were clustered in the metropolitan areas. This is a package about access and affordability. We identified that there was an equity problem in the way Medicare currently operates. Patients' costs for visiting a GP depended more on where they lived than on their ability to pay. That is why we developed significant scaling incentives to GPs, depending on their location, to bulk-bill some or all of their patients. The level of incentives rises substantially the more remote the practice is. They range from an average of $3,500 to an average of $22,050 each year. Those GPs who participate in the General Practice Access Scheme and whose practices are located in an urban area of work force shortage will also be eligible for assistance to employ a practice nurse. The government will provide $8,000 payment per full-time GP up to a maximum of $40,000 to hire a nurse for the practice. It has been estimated by some people that a full-time practice nurse relieves a doctor's practice of about the equivalent of 0.5 of a medical practitioner.

answer.para: This package has been fully costed and, unlike Labor's alternative, it is not coming out of a deficit budget, which they are very good running. It is not coming out of an increase in existing taxes. It is not coming out of the abolition of the private health insurance rebate. Senator Coonan referred to that a moment ago in answer to a question. Mr Crean has to come clean and tell the Australian publicâthose people who have private health insuranceâwhether they will be doing anything with the rebate. They ought to come out and commit. He keeps saying that they have a health policy. He has a portion of a policy. He has not admitted or told the Australian public what he is going to do about private health insurance or what they are going to do about the private health insurance rebate.

The Howard government has addressed the need to assist GPs to bulk-bill by providing a raft of measures and incentives to make the majority of GPs better off while, more importantly, remaining fiscally responsible. On the other hand we have the Labor Party, who have recently announced their untargeted $1.9 billion-dollar package that is unfunded. Whilst only retaining a number of our measures, they have provided no real incentives to get doctors into areas of work force shortage. They have provided a very expensive package which, as I said, is unfunded.

There are a number of taxes and rebates we know they have indicated that they will target to raise the funds. Will they increase the Medicare levy to fund their proposal? They have indicated on more than several occasions that this is a proposal worth consideringâit depends on who is at the helm at the time, and they get corrected from time to time by Mr Crean. Let me state that, for each half of a percentage point rise in the 1.5 per cent levy, a family with a household income of $50,000 faces an extra tax burden of $250 a year. If they wind back the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate, it will result in a tax rise for nine million Australians covered by private health insurance. The Labor Party has stated that it has the 30 per cent rebate under review. Abolishing the rebate will cost between $750 and $850 per year for a family covered by private health insurance. Will they take it off ancillaries? Doing that would mean Australian families would be $230 a year worse off. How will Mr Crean justify this to the 1.14 million Australians over the age of 60 who rely on access to ancillary benefits to enhance their quality of life with optometry, dentistry, physiotherapy et cetera? It is an important preventative measure against hospital admission. They would lose that benefit if Labor tampered with the private health insurance rebate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Family and Community services, Senator Vanstone. Is the government currently conducting a review of family tax benefit rules? Who is conducting this review? Can the minister confirm the Prime Minister's public statement that it is the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that has taken this policy area out of the hands of her department? Can the minister explain why this review has not been entrusted to her own department, given her responsibility for the payment? How should the Prime Minister's confirmation that his department is undertaking a review be considered with evidence from her department's officers at budget estimates hearings that `change is not being contemplated'?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for his question. I will not repeat what I have said about the benefits of this system, which pays $2 billion extra to families.
âWhat about the review? You've got to get to the question!

âJust loosen your jocks, Senator. I am answering a question from someone behind you, not you. Just give him a chance to listen to his answer. He asked the question. I believe him to be genuine. I believe he is interested in the answer. If you will just pipe down, I will be able to give him the answer. Senator Hogg, you asked about a review and referred to some statements made in estimates about no change being contemplated. Let me have a look at those because I will be able to see the context in which someone gave you that answer.

answer.para: It has been clearly understood for a very long time that the government is looking at work and family pressures. Of course, in looking at work and family pressures we will be looking at all family payments. It is in the context of work and family that any aspects touching familiesâwhich would include family tax benefit A and Bâare being looked at by a task force which is being chaired by PM&C and which includes my department, DEWR and some others. There is no big news here. There is a task force looking at work and family. It is an interdepartmental task force. It is chaired by Prime Minister and Cabinetâ

talk.start.para: âBut your own officers told us!
âSenator, I do not know what you sold before you came in here, but the voice matches one particular occupation. Senator Hogg, that is the answer to your question.

âMr President, in view of that answer, I have a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of comments by Alan Jones on 4 June 2003 about the minister's responsiveness on portfolio issues? He said:

quote.para: Well there's no pointâI can tell youâtalking to Amanda Vanstone. Every time I write to her you get eventually an arrogant and dismissive reply, which I have to say I return with an equally arrogant and dismissive reply. She is a complete waste of time, Amanda Vanstone, and a person with her lack of sensitivity towards these issues shouldn't be in this important Portfolio.

question.para: Is this the real reason further review of the family payments debacle has been taken over by the Prime Minister when his favourite broadcaster describes the minister as arrogant and dismissive?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âSenator, your question provides me with an opportunity that I will decline, other than to say that I was not aware that the Labor Party took character references from Alan Jones. I can assure you that I will never be applying for a job where I seek one from him.

âMy question is also addressed to the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Vanstone. Is the minister aware of the 10 June edition of the Bulletin which profiles the high level of domestic violence in Australia? Are she and the government also aware of the follow-up edition in which the Bulletin printed an open letter to the minister, entitled `Shame on you, Senator', where they discussed the government's decision to take $10.1 million out of the domestic violence prevention budget and put it into fridge magnet production? Is the government aware that this has been described as an `absurdity' by the Bulletin, which says:

quote.para: How a government that claims to care about this issue could even contemplate underspending on domestic violence is beyond explanation.

question.para: Can the minister give us an explanation for that decision in the budget and also give the Senate an assurance that that $10 million will be put back into the budget?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for the question because it gives me the opportunity to address some misconceptions repeated by the Bulletinâwhether they created them or not, I cannot say; others in this place may have had a hand in that. Let me make one thing clear: there are no services for women suffering from the effects of domestic violence that are in any way affected by the PADV funding. PADV is a Commonwealth initiative of $50 million to find better ways of preventing and responding to domestic violence. We committed $50 million and we will spend $50 million. The senator asked me: can I confirm that this money will be put back? If the senator was a genius at looking at budget statements, I think she would be able to see that that is the case and that that is there. She nods. I do not know whether she is acknowledging that she sort of implied she could not read the budget papers but now understands that it is there. In any event, the bottom line is this: the $50 million was committed, and the $50 million will be spent.

answer.para: With respect to the Bulletin, I would have thought a magazine of that standing would have known the facts in the first place and certainly would have bothered to check them so they did not create a fundamental misunderstanding. The misunderstanding is this: services to women who have suffered from domestic violence are paid for by the states. It is a state criminal offence to beat someone up behind closed doors, and the states deal with it. The Commonwealth some time ago said, `We will help you find new and innovative ways of dealing with this. That money is not for recurrent funding of services but rather to find these new and innovative ways of dealing with and preventing domestic violence.' As to the spending on those recurrent services, I might point outâand I would have pointed this out to the Bulletin if they had bothered to ring and make some inquiries to get their facts rightâthat the Commonwealth does of course assist the states in some of the funding for domestic violence, namely through funding for SAAP, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program. That provides shelters, which of course as you know, Senator, are a much-needed response to domestic violence once it has sadly happened and we have not been able to prevent it. The Commonwealth has had a very significant increase in its last SAAP agreement with the states, an increase which I note has not been matched by one single state.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, and I seek clarification. The minister's answer implied that the $10 million that was claimed to have been underspent is in fact being spent as part of that $50 million program. Could the minister advise the Senate: is it the case that that $10 million will be used as part of the domestic violence prevention program and that the overall budget will not be diminished by the $10 million as a consequence of the budget changes? Will the senator give an assurance to the Senate that any further programs will be implemented fully and that all funds that are allocated towards those programs will be spent accordingly?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank you, Senator. My advice is that this is clear in the budget papers. If you have missed it, I am sorry. I will get some advice as to how clear it is, but in any event, to save you the bother of going to the budget papers or just in case it is not clear in the budget papers, let me repeat what I have said to you and the answer I gave you a minute agoâand that was: $50 million has been committed and $50 million will be spent. But let me also make clear to you that I have a commitment to this issue that goes well beyond simply saying, `We have spent this money.' I will not sign off on projects if I do not think they are going to deliver appropriate outcomes. I would rather defer the spending of the money and get a better project and get a better outcome for the money than say, `Quickly, let's spend the money this year.' We made a $50 million commitment and we will spend it, as I said in my answer. But you can be sure of this: we will be spending it on projects that I believe are worth spending it on. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Environment: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Coonan, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Does the minister recall her media release of 6 June 2003, or 11 days ago, in relation to the Howard government's broken promise made in June 2000 to marine tourism operators that it would not collect the GST on the environmental management charge, or reef tax? Didn't this media release state:

quote.para: The Government has recently been advised that audit activity by the Australian Tax Office has revealed that there appears to be confusion or misunderstanding about whether the cost of the EMC should form part of the GST supply in tourism operators' ticket prices.

question.para: Can the minister now confirm that she had representations made to her on behalf of Adrenalin Dive from Townsville on 27 August and 10 September 2002, or some 10 months ago, in relation to the application of the GST on the reef tax? How then can the minister say that she was only recently advised of the problem, and what is the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer doing to assure marine park tourism operators that they will not have to pay this tax on a tax?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe EMC is not subject to GST when paid by the tourism operators. The government agreed that it would make a determination under division 81 of the GST act which exempts various Australian taxes, fees and charges from GST. The EMC is listed on the division 81 determination. This means that GST does not apply to the EMC when it is paid by the operators to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. However, as I indicated in my press release of 6 June 2003:

quote.para: The Government has recently been advised that audit activity by the Australian Tax Office has revealed that there appears to be confusion or misunderstanding about whether the cost of the EMC should form part of the GST supply in tourism operators' ticket prices ...

answer.para: It would appear that different approaches may have been used by various operators in the industry and, considering that significant unpaid GST liabilities may have accrued, the government is seeking urgent meetings, as I said in my press release, with representatives of the industry and the ATO to determine the extent and indeed the impact of any confusion. As I said in my press release, the government will work quickly with the industry to gain an appreciation of the extent of any problem and will look at what options may be available to determine an appropriate way forward. It is an example of the government listening to the concerns that are brought to it, not ignoring them but trying to gain an appreciation of where some confusion may have existed in the application of the law. There has been a significant transition time from the GST but the government does understand that occasionally these matters may not be fully understood and may not be appreciated and that it is appropriate that the government consults with the industry so that these confusions can be cleared up and a determination made about an appropriate way forward.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Doesn't the minister's media release also say:

quote.para: Senator Coonan said that the Government will work quickly with the industry to gain an appreciation of the extent of any problem ...

question.para: Why has it taken so long for this minister to gain an appreciation of the problem when the industry has been telling her of this for over 10 months? Why hasn't the minister delivered on the Howard government's promise to stop the tax office collecting the GST on the reef tax?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe government has listened to these concerns that have very recentlyâI think about a week agoâbeen brought to my attention; it was when I issued a press release. I think I have known about this matter for about a week, and there is a meeting later this week to determine the strategy to take the matter forward. It is entirely appropriate that we should do this and indeed it is very rare that you get a turnaround of that kind of speed: within one week that industry identifies an issue, there is a press release and a strategy devised to deal with the problem. I cannot imagine that Senator McLucas, when she thinks about it for more than a moment, could have any criticism of that.

âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, and it relates to the risk management regimes of and for the National Stem Cell Centre which was established last year. Given that taxpayers have invested some $43Â½ million in this centre, can the minister inform the Senate whether or not the Commonwealth has any legal obligations in respect of any dispute that may arise between the NSCC and participating organisations or third parties over intellectual property or the commercialisation of intellectual property or research outcomes?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âThe Commonwealth and the National Stem Cell Centre, the NSCC, did sign a deed of agreement establishing the Biotechnology Centre of Excellence on 30 May this year. Under that executed deed of agreement, the centre is defined as the Biotechnology Centre of Excellence. The centre will be operated by the centre institution, which is defined as National Stem Cell Centre Ltd, the NSCC, and includes the directors, officers, employees, agents and subcontractors of this centre institution where that is relevant. So the NSCC is a not-for-profit company limited by guarantee which is governed by the Corporations Act. The NSCC will enter into agreements with participating organisations and an affiliated commercial entity of the NSCC in order to carry out the NSCC's obligations under the deed executed with the Commonwealth. That recently signed deed of agreement required the company to have appropriate private insurance to protect itself, and I am advised that National Stem Cell Centre Ltd, which operates and has responsibility for the Biotechnology Centre of Excellence, is a company in its own right and that the Commonwealth has absolutely no liability for its activities.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the Commonwealth has the right, as I understand it, to approve or disapprove commercialisation arrangements, why wouldn't the Commonwealth have some legal responsibility if the NSCC were sued?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âI do not know that I can add much more to what I have said. The Commonwealth has executed this deed of agreement with the National Stem Cell Centre to operate the Biotechnology Centre of Excellence and the liability, as I am advised, under the deed of agreement does rest with National Stem Cell Centre Ltd. If there is any alteration to that in relation to your question, I will advise you as soon as I can. But I am confident that there is no liability on the Commonwealth; it rests with the NSCC under the deed.

âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Revenue, Senator Coonan. Can the Assistant Treasurer confirm that the budget papers contain a new revenue measure of $325 million over four years from departing nonresidents voluntarily transferring their superannuation back to their home country? Can the Assistant Treasurer confirm that the Taxation Office is desperately searching the world to attempt to find over one million former visitors to Australia, such as students, backpackers and various professionals to encourage them to transfer their superannuation so that the tax office can collect up to 40 per cent tax? Just five weeks after the budget was handed down, can the minister confirm that this tax revenue will be collected?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe announcement in the government's superannuation election statement, A Better Superannuation System, allows persons from 1 July 2002 who have entered Australia on an eligible temporary visa to access superannuation benefits upon permanent departure. The particular eligible temporary visas are listed in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations and the Retirement Savings Account Regulations. The measure does not extend to departing Australian citizens or permanent residents because, although these individuals may leave the country, they retain the option of retiring in Australia and accessing the age pension. Similarly, the measure is not intended to apply to New Zealand citizens working in Australia as they also have the option of retiring here and accessing the age pension.

answer.para: The situation is that there certainly is provision in the budget to deal with this measure and to allow those departing Australia permanently, in the categories that I have mentioned, to access their superannuation. In fact, as Senator Sherry identified in estimates, there have been various efforts and initiatives undertaken, particularly by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, to identify those who otherwise may be eligible to contact them so that they may be made aware of this measure. At the moment, it is not entirely clear just how easy it will be to identify those who have already departed.

The measures that are in place will certainly enable those who can be identified to make the claim in respect of their super once they have departed permanently. It is an initiative which is to be commended because there is really little point in having those who do not need to save for their retirement in this country having their funds tied up here, because when they have departed Australia permanently they incur fees, charges and administrative costs to retain those moneys here. So it is a sensible measure to enable those who are departing permanently to be able to access their superannuation and the framework will be carefully monitored so that the best possible efforts will be made to identify those who can claim.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister said that it is not entirely clear and she could not confirm that the tax revenue will be collected. Given that Treasury has admitted in Senate estimates that its estimated take-up rate of 80 per cent will need to be downgradedâit might be somewhat difficult to contact one million visitors when you do not have their addressesâpossibly to 20 per cent. How does the government propose to make up the resulting shortfall of some $245 million in funding its superannuation policies?
âWe have policies, Nick, and you haven't. How about your shortfall in funding? You have got no policy.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âAs usual, Senator Sherry pre-empts an outcome without knowing the facts and without having the vaguest idea of the basis on which he puts his question. As Senator Kemp reminds us, at least we have some superannuation policies. Senator Sherry's blank piece of paper remains obstinately blank, just like most of those on the other side when it comes to superannuation. Senator Sherry is worried about revenue. What he could do is pass the reduction in the surcharge so that those who are burdened unfairly in respect of superannuation can in fact access a measure that will give them some tax benefits.

âMr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. My question went to the issue of whether or not the minister believes that the budget paper revenue estimates to collect this tax from overseas departing residents will in fact be collected. She is not answering the question. Relevance!
âYou know the answer to that as well as I do, Senator Sherry. There is no point of order.

âMy question is to the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, Senator Ian Macdonald. Would the minister outline to the Senate recent steps that the Howard government has taken to address water and environmental issues in the Murray-Darling Basin, and is the minister aware of any alternative policy approaches?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âSenator Ferris is a South Australian and I know she has a very keen interest in the Murray-Darling River system. She will know that the Murray-Darling Basin Commission was formed 100 years ago to address concerns about the river system. It is currently led by a ministerial council consisting of three federal ministersâMr Truss is chairman; Dr Kemp, as the Minister for the Environment and Heritage; and me, as Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation. There are also nine state and territory ministers on the councilâall Labor of courseâand they are there because the states are the ones with responsibility and jurisdiction to allocate water resources.

answer.para: There are well documented concerns with the Murray-Darling Basin which have been scientifically assessed over many years, and they are highlighted as well by a very significant community consultation process that has been initiated by the ministerial council. At our last meeting in May, the council endorsed the Living Murray initiative and we agreed that at our November meeting we would consider a first-step decision which would mean no loss to existing water users but would get some environmental flows into the river and would consider the socioeconomic impacts of some possible solutions. But questions of water allocation are not those that the Commonwealth can address; they are questions that really have to be addressed by the states.

I am asked whether I am aware of any alternatives. I did hear the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Crean, make a bit of a statement after the budget. He came up with a policy for the Murray-Darling. It appears that this issue eventually came to his attention after he visited the Murray mouth, apparently for the very first time ever. With this new-found interest in the Murray-Darling he announced a new deal. He is going to restore enough environmental flow to keep the mouth openânot enough flow, obviously, to address the other critical issues of the Murray-Darling Basin, but he will find enough to keep the mouth open. There is not a word about where he is going to get it from, not a word on how he is going to get the state Labor governments to restrict allocations to find the water that he is going to use to keep the mouth open, and not a mention, I might add, of the huge socioeconomic implications which can destroy farms and communities.

How is Mr Crean going to do this? Have a look at his speech in reply to the budget. He does have a simple solution. He is going to do it by preventing drought. That is how he is going to do it. He is going to prevent droughts in the future. I know he can pluck roosters, as Senator Conroy can well attest, but how is he going to prevent droughts? He is going to do that by ratifying a treatyâby signing a bit of paper. By signing that paper he is going to stop all droughts in the future. Never mind the disadvantage to Australian industry or workers' jobs. I might add that it will not have any environmental impact, because the big greenhouse emittersâthe USA, Russia, China and Indiaâare not restricted by this treaty. But he is going to do it by stopping drought and by throwing in $150 million. He does not say what that is for or where it comes from. As the respected radio commentator and former Labor environment minister, Graham Richardson, said about this proposal:

quote.para: You are not going to save the Murray with $150 million, that's for sure. It needs a hell of a lot more than that but mostly it needs state governments to change water policy and federal governments just can't do that.

answer.para: If that is what passes for Labor policy, bring back Kim Beazley. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIs the minister aware of comments recently made by the member for Parramatta that Australians forced to pay for their own health care were `whingers' who made him want to throw up? Isn't it the case that the Parliamentary Secretary for Family and Community Services has publicly confirmed, firstly, that under the government's unfair Medicare package Australian families will pay more for seeing a doctor, and, secondly, that the government believes that they should just stop whingeing about the collapse of bulk-billing?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: âThe issue of Medicare, particularly primary health care delivery, has concerned me since I became health minister. As I said earlier in answer to a question from Senator Eggleston, when I looked very closely at the data I was very concerned about the inequity of access and affordability for people on very low incomes, particularly people who had health care cards. Labor had never cared about thatâthey had done nothing about it. We inherited, as I have said over and again in this chamber, a maldistribution of general practitionersâfar too many in the city, where we had very high bulk-billing rates, and too few in the country and outer metropolitan areas. Bulk-billing rates were very much reflected by the number of doctors in those areas. Labor never cared about it. I will not be so unkind as to say that that they did not care about it in rural areas because they have fewer constituents there, but senators have a responsibility to constituents in rural areas.

answer.para: I found that there were people who had very low incomes who had never seen the likes of a bulk-billing doctor. It did not seem fair to me that someone on our salaries or on my salary could be bulk-billed in downtown Camberwell and that people in rural centres had never ever seen a bulk-billing doctor. We introduced legislation to increase the likelihood of people on health care cards being bulk-billed by introducing targeted incentives to increase the likelihood of people on health care cards being bulk-billed. We have done an assessment which shows that the vast majority of doctors, if they were to sign up to the package, would be better off.

I am not going to make a comment about people's views about paying for health. We have one of the best health systems in the world. For example, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme people with a health care card pay $3.70 for the most commonly prescribed medications which cost $80 per person per month. We have just introduced onto the PBS a medication that costs about $26,000 per person per year. That is the level of assistance that people are getting under our health schemeâpaying $3.70 on a health care card and paying $23.10 if they are not until they reach the safety net.

It is a very generous scheme. But it will be very vulnerable if we do not care for it and look after it and if we do not make sure that people understand the huge benefits that they receive from the taxpayer through the MBS rebate for general practitioners' services, through the MBS rebate for specialist services, through the PBS and through the $42 billion we are offering the states for their public hospitals. It is an enormous contribution to health from the public purse. Australians understand and appreciate it, but we all have to understand that it is going up at a significant rate, particularly the PBS. I call on the Senate to reconsider the legislation before the chamber and to look at the modest increase in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to ensure that all our health systemâacross Medicare, the PBS, general practice, specialists and public hospitalsâis affordable.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister for Health and Ageing aware that the business manager of a Melbourne general practice has endorsed the government's Medicare package for the reason that `the key advantage of the coalition plan was that participating practices could offset the cost of bulk-billing concessional patients by charging other patients extra'? Is not this expert confirmation of what the member for Parramatta was saying: that most families will pay more for medical services under the Howard government? Why won't the government admit what health experts, doctors and many health patients already know: that its proposed `swipe card' arrangement will make it possible for doctors to charge copayments for patients whom they currently bulk-bill and easier for doctors to increase their existing fees for everyone else?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: âSenator Hutchins has been very busy looking after issues relating to leadership in his party, but he has not been out in the community to find out what the community actually thinks. If he were to go out into the community and talk to people whose doctors choose not to bulk-bill themâand there have always been, since the inception of Medicare, doctors who choose not to bulk-bill all of their patients, some of their patients, a majority of their patients or only those patients who have recently come to their practiceâand if he were to go to a Medicare office and talk to the people standing waiting to get their Medicare rebate, they would say to him: `Why do I have to do this? Why do I have to wait for my Medicare rebate in the mail if I choose to send it in by post? Why do I have to go down to the Medicare office for my rebate?' Senator Hutchins and those on the other side have been so busy and so preoccupied with their leadership that they have failed to go out and listen to what people are saying. That is what they are saying, and they will remind them that they do not want to have to go to a Medicare office to get their rebate.

âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Can the Assistant Treasurer explain why the Commonwealth Grants Commission effectively encourages the WA and the ACT governments to increase the revenue they raise from gambling? Does this not make a mockery of the Prime Minister's promise in 1999 that the Commonwealth would lead the way in solving problem gambling? Why won't the government offer the state grants commissions incentives to reduce their reliance on gambling revenue?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThank you, Senator Allison, for the question. It is not my portfolio.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Assistant Treasurer advise which department then takes care of the Commonwealth Grants Commission matters? It is my understanding it is Treasury.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âIt is Senator Minchin's portfolio.
âSenator Minchin?
âSenator Allison, I do not think you can redirect your question.

âMy question is to Senator Patterson, the Minister for Health and Ageing. Can the minister confirm that in the last week of May the government made an extraordinary payment totalling $30 million to 4,600 general practitioners throughout Australia with no strings attachedâan average payment of $6,800 for each general practice? Is it not the case that, while the government claims that this money is to assist doctors to upgrade their patient records, there will be no requirement for doctors to use the money to improve patient records, no accountability or acquittal for this $30 million and no mechanism by which the money will have to be repaid to the government if the upgrading of patient records is not done? Isn't the complete lack of accountability for this end-of-financial-year gift to doctors the reason that some doctors have described the payment as `money for jam'?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: âWe went through this issue quite extensively in estimates. I do not know whether the honourable senator has sat downâand he should haveâand read all those estimates questions: Senator McLucas's long questions and Senator Nettle's long questions. They will be very entertaining for him to read when he has nothing to do on a long plane journey. I presume he has not read them. I do not think he was there and I did not expect him to be there because he is not a member of that committee.

answer.para: We did give doctors funding for IT. Honourable senators might have read this morning in the IT section of the Australianâit might have been the Ageâthat general practitioners are further ahead than most other sections of the health care industry in working towards being computerised. It is important to have computerised information in a general practice, and we are ensuring that with our practice incentive payments which go only to doctors who have been accredited as practice incentive payment general practitioners. That means they have to go through an accreditation process and be involved in delivering better health outcomes in terms of asthma programs and mental health programs, which the Labor Party never cared about. They never funded doctors to deliver outcomes for people to manage chronic diseases like diabetes, asthma and mental health. The practitioners who have taken up the Practice Incentive Program do things like recalling patients for pap smears or for extra visits for their asthma programs. This money came out of the PIP program and it was to assist doctors in upgrading, entering or improving their data. There will be further funding for which they will be required to give evidence that they have used that funding and how they are going to use the future funding.

The funding was to ensure that we have doctors as up to date as possible to reduce red tape. That is an issue that they have been concerned about. We now have a task force in my department, with various PM&C representatives, to reduce red tape. The doctors argue that, as these programs have developed, they have increased their administrative load. This will be reduced the more that they are computerised. In fact, I went to a practice recently on the North Coast of New South Wales. The young doctor there has computerised her whole practice and also the Practice Incentive Program. She said that she does not see that she has a red tape problem. So we need to simplify the Practice Incentive Program and make sure general practitioners are as up to date as possible with their IT, because we will then be able to deliver better primary health care and better outcomes. That is what we are interested in. The sort of thing the Labor Party are focusing on is the level of bulk-billing and that seems to be the only issue that they have in their health policy.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't it the case that the $30 million payment to doctors was made indiscriminately to all registered practices, whether or not the practice already had fully computerised records or, in fact, had no other electronic records at all? Isn't it also the case that, if the government had not rushed to splurge this $30 million of taxpayers' money before the end of this financial year, the money could have been spent on other health priorities? Would this money not have been better spent paying for the equivalent of 1.2 million bulk-billed GP consultations?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: âAs I indicated, this money was to assist practices that needed to get further up to date, to reward practices that got up to date and also to ensure that we have general practice as highly ITed and as highly up to date in terms of their computerisation as possible because it assists them in spending more time with their patients. As health minister, I want to assist them to do thatârather than filling out formsâto be able to be with their patients and have practices whereby they can recall their patients who are due for checks on diabetes or for cervical screening and all the other things that general practices ought to be doing in terms of improving health outcomes for Australians.
âMr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âYesterday I took a question on notice from Senator Wong in relation to questions relating to the minister for immigration. I now have that information and I seek leave to table it as well as to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
Mr Handâ81 cases.
Senator Bolkusâ311 cases.
Mr Ruddockâ1751 cases as at 30 April 2003, according to current departmental records.
There are no data available for the period that Senator Ray was the responsible minister.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âYesterday Senator Bishop asked me a question about the sugar industry reform program and exceptional circumstances. I referred that to Mr Truss and I can advise that, when assessing applications for the sugar industry reform program and exceptional circumstances relief, Centrelink takes all forms of income, including DVA pensions, into account when determining rates of payment. I should add that veterans can access business support elements of the exceptional circumstances package and also interest rate subsidies offered under the sugar industry reform package.

speech.para: For exceptional circumstances, veterans can access the interim interest rate relief and also, when an area is declared in full EC, they can access interest rate subsidies of up to $100,000 per year over two years. Under the sugar industry reform package, veterans are entitled to access interest rate subsidies on loans of up to $50,000 to meet expenses incurred in the planting of sugar cane. Further advice is available from Centrelink on 1800 050 585. In relation to the supplementary question, Centrelink does not maintain statistics for pensions that may contribute to rejection of an application or reduction of assistance.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health and Ageing (Senator Patterson) to a question without notice asked by Senator Hutchins today relating to Medicare and the decline in the rate of bulk billing.

speech.para: This afternoon I asked the Minister for Health and Ageing a question in relation to Medicare and bulk-billing. I asked, in particular, a question in reference to a statement made by the member for Parramatta, Mr Ross Cameron, who is also the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services. In May of this year, for some unknown reason, Mr Cameron decided he needed his profile raised a little bit and he went and, no doubt, sought out Mr Matt Price from the Australian to add to the situation that the coalition was trying to foster in its changes to both health and education.

Mr Cameron said that baby boomers made him sick; they made him want to throw up. He said he was prepared to risk unpopularity in his electorate because of these baby boomers who think they can get a free ride in both education and health. He saidâI do not know for what reason; maybe he is competing for some sort of vacancy that may occur in the government's front benchâthis made him absolutely throw up. I will tell you what made people in his electorate throw up: the fact that he decided to go and broadcast this in the Australian. For all I know, he was trying to impress some sort of intelligentsia, but I am sure he did not think people in Parramatta read the Australian. Unfortunately for him, the people who go and visit Dr Greg Lahood at the Oaklands general practice in Parramatta do. The people who queue up to see Dr Lahood on occasion to be treated for their medical problems do.

One thing about Dr Lahood that you do not know about, Mr Deputy President, is this: Dr Lahood is a bulk-biller and is Mr Cameron's family doctor. There is our Rosco queuing up, like everybody else who needs to be attended by a doctor, with his Medicare card, getting it flashed over the counter. That is our parliamentary secretary for family and community services. That is our parliamentary secretary who said baby boomers make him want to throw up. That is the man we have identified today as one of the hypocrites that we see all too oftenâ

talk.start.para: âI think you need to withdraw that, Senator Hutchins.

âI will withdraw `hypocrite', Mr Deputy President. Scroungers like Mr Cameron, the member for Parramatta, think they can say these comments in the Australian and not have constituents in Parramatta let me know about it. You would be surprised, Mr Deputy President, at the number of men and womenâwho, like Mr Cameron, use Dr Lahood as their general practitioner and who go to him because he is a bulk-billerâand how incensed and outraged they were when they saw Mr Cameron's comments. Because Mr Cameron said people like them make him throw upâand there he is, queuing up like everybody else to get free medical care. But it does not end there. If you look at Mr Cameron's contribution to the parliamentary diaries and biographies, you will see Mr Cameron, who said people who go after free health and education make him throw up, is a graduate of the University of Sydney in both economics and law.

speech.para: Let me tell you about Mr Cameron, who is to the manor born. He does not come from any poor or struggling background; he is well and truly to the manor born, like a number of our colleagues on the other side. Mr Cameron paid one year's HECS for his dual degrees, which we estimate would have cost about $100,000. He paid for one yearâthe largesse of this man, who is dripping in money and who was born to it! Let me tell you why he did that. He felt a bit of shame about the hundred grand that he had ripped out of the system so he donated $2,000 to the education department to support his conviction that students should pay for their education. So here we have this scrounger who not only goes to the bulk-billers in his own electorate but also has bludged on the system to have his education paid forâfree. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI stand to respond to this motion to take note of answers, and I refute categorically and in total the words and allegations thrown at a member of the House of Representatives, the federal member for Parramatta, Mr Ross Cameron, who is a decent, honest, hardworking and very effective member of this government. Not only that, I believe that some of Senator Hutchins's words were unparliamentary, Mr Deputy President, particularly the word `scrounger'. I did not take a point of order at the time because I knew I would have the opportunity to respond. I think the words were totally inappropriate and I think an apology should be offered to the member for Parramatta, Ross Cameron.

speech.para: Senator Hutchins, you highlighted the fact that, of his own free will, Mr Cameron paid that one-year HECS fee. He did that because of his own views that it would be in the best interests of this nation and in the public interest, so I commend him for that. He is a man who stands up for an incentive approach and smaller government and lower taxes, unlike those on the other side. In fact, Senator Hutchins is acting like a wounded bull this afternoon because he clearly backed the wrong horse yesterday, and that has shown up in his salacious allegations against the Hon. Ross Cameron, the federal member for Parramatta.

If you truly believe the wild allegations made by the Labor Party and some in the media with respect to this government's position on bulk-billing, you will think that we have actually cut funding to Medicare. What nonsense. Those opposite know it is nonsense because it is on the record that the proposal is for a $917 million injection into bulk-billing and Medicare and to ensure there are more GPs in rural and regional Australia. That is the condemnation that will be on their own heads. It is totally inappropriate to say these things when they know the facts. I say `res ipsa loquitur'âthe facts speak for themselves: a proposal to increase funding by nearly a billion dollars. But according to the Labor Party and those others opposite who oppose this proposal we are cutting or slashing funding to Medicare and bulk-billing.

With respect to the Medicare rebate, let us have a look at the record since 1996 and then at the record under Labor. Under the coalition government, the Medicare rebate for a standard consultation has increased by $4.20, or 20 per cent. But what about under Labor? In the last six years of the Labor government the Medicare rebate for a standard consultation rose by only $1.70, or less than nine per cent. Those on the other side were talking about hypocrisy; they should take some of that medicine. We stand on our record of a 20 per cent increase compared with Labor's nine per cent.

Remember that in Australia today seven out of 10 services to the GP are still bulk-billed. All Australians visit their GPs, to the tune of almost $2.8 billion last calendar year. I want to highlight the fact that we are trying to get GP and medical services into rural and regional areas. Under this package, in places like Ross, Oatlands, Queenstown and St Helens, in Tasmania, we are giving $22,000 extra every year to those GPs who sign up. That is vital for those rural and regional areas to ensure that those health services are provided. Why won't Labor support it? In towns like Launceston, Burnie and Devonport $18,500 is being provided to those GPs who sign up. Come on, let's get real; let's get support for this package. With respect to increasing the number of doctors, 234 new medical places have just been announced. I congratulate Senator Kay Patterson, the Minister for Health and Ageing, on that announcement. It is good news for Tasmania. We have an extra 21 places, bringing the total up to 83 new medical places at the University of Tasmania.

I spoke to Professor Allan Carmichael only last week about it. How pleased are they? They are very pleased with this initiative and the new medical places at the University of Tasmania. Of course, Western Australian and Queensland universities are falling over themselves with delight because of the new services being offered in those states. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: âI rise to contribute to this motion to take note of answers. It is often the case in this place that we have quite a protracted debate about the delivery of health care services because it is one of the fundamental differences between our side of politics and those opposite. When we engage in this debate, we often have the minister prattle on about how the federal government are paying their way and how they are doing this fantastic job and the problem is that the states do not commit enough money, that they underspend and that they are cutting spending.

speech.para: Have I got news for the minister: over the past three years in my home state of Western Australia, the Western Australian state government has increased funding to the health budget by an average of seven per cent per annum. That is an enormous real increase as well as a numerical increase. In fact, in the next financial year Western Australia will increase its health budget by over 9.5 per cent. These are all figures that are on the public record; yet the minister comes in here and bleats about how she cannot get a commitment up-front from the states and about how they are going to fund the delivery of health care services. This is at a time when she is reducing her commitment to the delivery of health care services and is placing added pressure on our Medicare system.

In the year 1999-2000, which is the latest year for which data is available, the Commonwealth spent $1,227 per person on health services in Western Australia compared to $1,370 per person nationally. It would seem there is a bit of an underspend from the federal government in my home state. If the Commonwealth had spent the national average in Western Australia, then it would have provided approximately $30 million more for the delivery of health care services in that year alone. Similarly, in 2001-02 Commonwealth expenditure in Western Australia under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, another scheme that everyone should be familiar with, averaged $189 per Western Australian compared to the national average of $214 per person. So how is it that the minister can keep coming in here saying that the problem is always with the states, that they are not committed to the delivery of health care services and that she is doing such a fantastic job?

Add to that the decline in bulk-billing rates throughout Western Australia. Bulk-billing rates nationally have declined by about 12 per cent. In Western Australia the electorate that has been hardest hit with the decline is the electorate of O'Connor where you are lucky to have access to GP services anyway, never mind being able to find a doctor that bulk-bills. Add to that the difficulties that people have in the electorate of Kalgoorlie. If you go further north than the town of Geraldton, which is only a five-hour drive from Perthâso you can imagine there is a huge distance to go after thatâyou will not find the delivery of GP or private health care services anywhere. Every bit of the provision of health care services is done by salaried doctors or through the public hospital system.

Another area of disadvantage that Western Australians face at the hands of the Commonwealth government is in the allocation of HECS based domestic medicine placesâand I am glad that Senator Barnett brought that up. In the year 2000, for example, the Commonwealth government allocated only 125 commencing undergraduate medicine places to Western Australian universities compared to 148 places allocated to South Australia. South Australia, I do not need to remind you, is a much smaller size and has a much smaller population than Western Australia. The minister with great fanfare announced recently that Western Australia would be allocated an additional 40 places in the new roundâ20 to the University of Western Australia and 20 to the full fee private University of Notre Dame. An extra 40 places does not go anywhere near the number of doctors we need to deliver health care services throughout Western Australia.

One of the other areas having a significant impact on the delivery of health care services is the funding crisis in the area of aged care. In Western Australia the state government expects to pay for 29,030 bed days in the hospital system for care-awaiting-placement patients this year. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis debate is supposed to be about the answers of the Minister for Health and Ageing to questions about the health care system, but so far it seems to have been an opportunity, firstly, for Senator Hutchins to make a fairly visceral attack on the member for Parramatta and, secondly, for Senator Webber to engage in some special pleading for Western Australia. I would prefer that the Senate focused on the real issues inherent in the minister's answers to questions today, which are the future funding of public hospitals in Australia and the future of the Medicare system as a way of Australians being able to access essential health services both from GPs and in hospitals.

speech.para: What the government has announced in recent weeks constitutes, I think, the most significant platform of improvements and reforms that this parliamentâcertainly this countryâhas seen in a very long time. It has been met characteristically on the part of the Labor Party by a complete wall of deception and misinformation about what those changes represent. We have seen Labor claimingâand I have only this week in the ACT seen literature from Labor membersâthat under the government's reforms bulk-billing will be available only for concession card holders. We all know that is not true. The government is especially placing resources at the disposal of doctors to encourage them to ensure that their concession card holders are universally bulk-billed. There is nothing in this package that affects the capacity of doctors to bulk-bill other patients who come through their doors. Indeed, measures like the simplification of claims arrangements and the simplification of red tape associated with doctors' practices will mean that doctors have the capacity to bulk-bill more of their patients because it will be administratively easier to do so.

We heard the claim from Senator Webber that Senator Patterson is reducing our commitment to the health system in the payments to Western Australia. What absolute nonsense! The minister has announced $917 million extra for Medicare in this country. How is that a reduction in commitment to the health system? She has announced $10 billion extra for public hospitals in this country with the quite reasonable caveat attached to that spending that the states make some effort to match that funding in light of the fact that we have seen in recent years a number of states take the opportunity of increased Commonwealth funding to withdraw or reduce their own funding to their own services. Then they have the temerity to turn around and blame the Commonwealth for the declining availability of services in the public hospitals and in surgeries. Anybody who cares about the quality of health care in this country would have to see measures of the kind announced by the government as a very important step in the right direction.

I think that what the member for Parramatta was saying is that those who can afford to pay should and the government should target its assistance to those who cannot. The package the government has announced is doing precisely that. It is targeting those people who are concession card holders and providing them with the access to GP services which they are not getting at the moment. Let me remind members opposite that the decline in access to bulk-billing doctors is not a feature of this government; it has been a continuing feature since the earliest days of the Medicare system. It has been going on for a number of years. Access to bulk-billing doctors was declining during the Hawke and Keating governments as well.

What has this government done, not just in this most recent announcement but before that, to improve health outcomes for Australians? We have increased spending on Medicare by $2 billion, from $6 billion to $8 billion. We are investing $560 million in the Rural Health Strategy to target the health of rural and regional Australians. We have committed $80 million to an outer metropolitan program to encourage more GPs into those areas. Around seven out of 10 of all GP services are delivered at no cost to patients. Close to eight out of every 10 GP services to patients aged 65 years and over are provided at no cost to the patient. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: âI also rise to speak on the motion to take note of answers given by the Minister for Health and Ageing. This is a government up to its neck in bad judgments and bad policies when it comes to the health portfolio. As we have heard today, the government has blown over $30 million by depositing an average payment of $6,800 into the bank accounts of general practices registered for the Practice Incentive Program, with nothing required or expected of them in return. The government argues that this money is to be used to upgrade patient record systems so that they are computerised. However, there is no mechanism at all by which the money will have to be repaid if practices do not upgrade their systems. Effectively, over $30 million has been handed out for nothing in return. This `no strings attached' payment, as doctors have called it, is just money for jam. It is an absolute disgrace.

speech.para: While the government hands out untied grants to doctors, the nationwide rate of bulk-billing continues to decline. In the March quarter, the rate of bulk-billing by GPs fell a further 1.1 percentage points to reach a new low of 68.5 per cent. Since coming to office, the Howard government has presided over a system in which the rate of bulk-billing by GPs has fallen by more than 12 per cent and the average cost of seeing a doctor who does not bulk-bill has risen by more than 55 per cent. Given these facts, $30 million in untied grants to doctors is an atrocious policy decision. $30 million would have been much better spent in funding over 1.2 million bulk-billing visits to the doctor.

This government has an awful track record on funding priorities, particularly when it comes to the health portfolio. It was recently revealed that $140,000 was spent by the government on consultancy fees to invent the Orwellian tag A Fairer Medicare and to sell the package to a sceptical Australian public. Those funds alone could have been used to support more than 5,500 GP visits. For a government that prides itself on supposed sound economic management, one can take little heart from the facts I have just presented. Moreover, the government has shown scant regard for the financial impact of its Medicare package, and is proceeding with it on the basis that it makes good ideological sense, not on the basis that it is sound economic and social policy. The government has failed to take into account when formulating its package the likely inflationary effects of the policy. It is blindly proceeding in the mere belief that fees will not rise, yet it has failed to produce any evidence or facts to support that belief.

As has been revealed, no regulatory impact statement has been prepared with respect to the so-called A Fairer Medicare package. This is another disgrace, given that the package is the most fundamental change to Medicare in decades. According to the Treasury, the RIS process is intended to ensure that a comprehensive assessment of all policy options and associated costs and benefits is undertaken. The information is then used to inform the decision making process. In that regard, it provides a comprehensive check list that outlines public policy decision making best practice. Why would the government fail to produce such a statement if it were satisfied the policy were financially and socially sound? I would suggest simply because it is not satisfied that that is the case.

This government's Medicare package is simply due to the Prime Minister's fundamental opposition to a universal health care system. During the 1980s, Mr Howard labelled Medicare `a miserable, cruel fraud', `a scandal', `a total and complete failure', `a quagmire', `a total disaster', `a financial monster' and `a human nightmare'. He threatened to `pull Medicare right apart' and to `get rid of the bulk-billing system'. Bulk-billing, Mr Howard said, was an `absolute rort'. The Howard government of 2003 is in the process of delivering on Mr Howard's 1980s threats.

In contrast, Labor's $1.5 billion Medicare plan will stem the catastrophic decline in bulk-billing and make it available for more Australians by immediately lifting the Medicare patient rebate to 95 per cent of the scheduled fee for all bulk-billed consultations. Labor would subsequently lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulk-billed consultations to 100 per cent of the scheduled fee. Labor would offer doctors powerful financial incentives of up to $22,500 to meet bulk-billing targets which are realistic and achievable and would provide for more GPs in the areas that need them and more nurses to assist GPs in their work. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer (Senator Coonan) to a question without notice asked by Senator Allison today relating to revenue from gambling taxes.

speech.para: I wish to challenge Senator Coonan on the issue of whose portfolio has responsibility for this matter. I did a quick check of the web site for the Commonwealth Grants Commission. It says:

quote.para: Although references are provided by the Minister for Finance and Administration, their content is usually decided in negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States, conducted largely through their Treasuries.

speech.para: Clearly, the Treasury is involved in the Commonwealth Grants Commission arrangements and the minister should have been able to answer my questions. If we go to the Treasury web site, we will find similar information. Commonwealth-state financial relations are within Treasury. The web site says:

quote.para: Commonwealth-State Financial Relations Division provides advice on Commonwealth-State financial relationsâ

speech.para: as you would expectâ

quote.para: fiscal developments in the States and Territories as well as the total public sector ...

speech.para: One of the reasons that the Assistant Treasurer was reluctant to answer my question is that this government has done very little about problem gambling. It is outrageous, particularly given the Prime Minister's promise in 1999 that the federal government would take the lead on problem gambling.
