As Senator Crossin knows, a significant number of people in the Northern Territoryâespecially in very remote areas like Katherine and a number of other areas which I will not go through but which I have visitedâhave had their health services significantly improved as a result of the coalition increasing the funding and almost doubling it.

speech.para: It is very easy to come into the chamber and make quick, cheap points about what the Commonwealth is not doing without actually indicating what it is doing. Some of the other speakers here todayâand maybe I should go into this debate in more detail tomorrow morning so that my speech looks a bit more coherent in one pieceâhave said that money has been taken out of the health care agreements. I absolutely refute that. The Commonwealth has in fact offered $10 billion more. That is a 17 per cent increase over and above inflation from the current health care agreements. How that can be taking money out of the health system beggars beliefâa 17 per cent increase. It does not matter; the people on the other side still make the comment that it is taking money out of the health system. We actually gave the state health system a $2.5 billion windfall in the life of the last agreement. I have not heard one member on the other side get up and say that. They say we are taking money out when it is a 17 per cent increase over and above inflation in the next five years. How that is a decrease beggars belief. They do not mention that there was a $2.5 billion windfall to the states when we did not claw back funding, as agreed in the life of the last health care agreement.

talk.start.para: (Senator Knowles)âOrder! There being no consideration of government documents, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI just want to make some brief remarks on how pleased I am that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 [No. 2] has been carried by the Senate because I think it is an important piece of legislation. It does reflect, I think, certainly from the Labor Party's point of view, the need for that original legislationâwhich was totally unacceptableâto be rejected and for amendments to have been made to make it a much more balanced piece of legislation. It balances the need for the security of Australians and the need for ASIO to be able to exercise its role in combating terrorism with protecting the rights of our citizens.

speech.para: It is a difficult balance at the best of times, but I think that, in the legislation now before the parliament, the Senate will have played a very useful role in trying to make sure that we have got that balance right. I have received a lot of representations from constituents about these issues. I know there is a lot of concern that we do get the balance right. I congratulate Senator John Faulkner, our parliamentary leader, on the work he and his staff have put in to try to make sure that we get a much better piece of legislation than was originally proposed.

subdebateinfo.title: General Douglas MacArthur Brisbane Memorial Trust
Aviation: Bakers Creek Air Crash

talk.start.para: âThe great project to establish a MacArthur Museum in Brisbane, in the very place where the general had his office during World War II, has marked two very significant milestones recently. There was a significant victory on budget nightâa further victory indeed for General Douglas MacArthur. The Howard Government agreed to provide $350,000 towards the development of the MacArthur Museum in the Heritage listed MacArthur Chambers site in central Brisbane. The other milestone was the handing over by the Brisbane City Council to the General Douglas MacArthur Brisbane Memorial Trust of the MacArthur Museum floor site. This handover took place at City Hall in Brisbane just last week.

speech.para: It was of course from the premises in Edward Street that General MacArthur directed the Allied war effort in the South-West Pacific during the dark days of 1942 to 1944 when Australia was under direct enemy threat and actual attackâand in my part of Australia, Queensland, particularly so. We must always remember our history, for history is not just a collection of dry facts but indeed the story of our nation's life. It is a proud story and none more proud than the part in which the Americans played such a significant and, indeed, a lifesaving part during the Pacific war, from 1941 to 1945.

Tonight I want to give honourable senators an overview of this magnificent project and also place on the record the thanks that are due to a great many people whose dedication, energy and fortitude have brought the project to its present pointâand I will come back to that in a minute. I thought too that this would be an appropriate time to make some comments about friends and neighbours, about steadfast allies and brave defenders of democracy. It is an appropriate time too to say a little about the heritage that the great English, Scots, Welsh and Irish diaspora of the past four centuries has brought us. It is time to say something about how we 21st century Australians have benefited so greatly from the global dispersion of English-speaking and Gaelic-speaking people and the precepts that brought democracy and true people's rule to the wide swathes of our planet. We in Australia, from whatever background we may come, are protected by that heritage and, by our actions and our way of governing ourselves, we protect it in its turn. We are a proud and very effective part of that global enlightenment.

Sixty years ago, at a time of great peril, Australia and America stood shoulder to shoulder in the Pacific to beat back tyranny. The bonds we forged then between our nations still endure and will, I believe, endure forever, just as will our bonds with Britain. You might indeed say that we are partâa proud and independent partâof an enduring empire. The empire of decency, democracy and common law, the rule of law, the supremacy of the ballot box and the determination to stand up for those in peril from others are all things that we share. They are an indelible part of our shared history and common culture. Let no-one ever get away with saying that time and events have reduced these gifts we hold in common and in trust for future generations to the status of a historical footnote or the irrelevance of a marginal comment.

At this time 60 years on we are again shoulder to shoulder with the Americans and the British in defence of liberty and the global assault on murderous terror. The events that have so shockingly opened the 21st century add a particular poignancy and a pointed relevance to our celebration of the great cause in which we, the Americans and ourselves, made a stand together six decades ago. Projects such as the MacArthur Museum give a much needed and very valuable public dimension to these links.

On completion of the building works at MacArthur Chambers, the MacArthur Museum will be open to the public as a managed wartime display. It will be an integral part of Brisbane's Living Heritage Network. Public interest in and educational exposure to Australia's heritage, Brisbane's military history and Queensland's tourist sites are increasingly evident in both our own and the international community. This is indeed an idea whose time has come.

The idea of course is not just to create a memorial to one fixed time in history. The MacArthur Museum, and indeed the whole MacArthur Chambers project, will go beyond a public display of Brisbane's involvement in the critical phase of the war in the South-West Pacific. It will add immeasurably, in my view, to the rich portfolio of sites in Brisbane's Living Heritage Network and social history. It will raise awareness of the heritage sector and its valuable contribution to the city of Brisbane. It will provide a focus on the historical awareness of visitors and the community, particularly our youth. It will provide a central point for military research and study. It will link sites such as the Australian War Memorial, Queensland's John Oxley Library, the Queensland University of Technology, the MacArthur Foundation in the USA and other military history related sites.

That the project has got to this point and will now move on to fruition is to the great credit of a large number of people. In particular, it is appropriate to mention the steering committee which is chaired by Major General M. Blake AO, MC. In the context of the steering committee, I want particularly to give credit to my friend Mr Geoff Thomas, Chairman of CapitalCorp Financial Services and, as well, Queensland's Special Commissioner to the United States, where his political and business connections are impeccable. Mr Thomas is truly a quiet achiever. He is also a very hard man to say no to, as will have become obvious very quickly to those he tirelessly lobbied on behalf of this great project. He approached me about the MacArthur Museum 2Â½ years ago and provided me with additional awareness of the project. Throughout this period he has pushed and encouraged me to never give up on pursuing financial and other support for the project. Those who value the MacArthur Museum project, I am sure, value Mr Thomas's interest in and support for it.

Also on the steering committee is Mr Geoff Rodgers, Managing Director of the Rowland Communications Group, who is deputy chairman. I have previously in this place recognised by name the other members of the steering committee and I again pay tribute to them tonight. In particular, I mention two other individuals: Lieutenant Colonel J.P. Dwyer AM, who is the executive officer, and the Patron of the General Douglas MacArthur Brisbane Memorial Trust, Major General Peter Arnison, the Governor of Queensland. I again recognise that the Queensland government and the Brisbane City Council have been behind the project from the start and, of course, so has the federal government, as has been newly demonstrated by the $350,000 grant made available in the recent federal budget.

The chairman of trustees is Sir Leo Hielscher, Chairman of the Queensland Treasury Corporation. The other trustees are the Premier of Queensland, the Hon. Peter Beattie, retired US Major William A. Bentson, Major General Digger James, Dr Leo Keliher as Director-General of the Premier's department, and Mr Ken Talbot of MacArthur Coal. It should also be placed on the record that the MacArthur family in America has given permission for the family name to be used in the Brisbane project. Under the development program, establishment of the full museum is contingent on recurrent funding, although the refurbishment of the MacArthur Chambers site commenced in late 2001 under commercial developers.

Phase 1 includes the restoration of General MacArthur's World War II office and refurbishment of the eighth-floor museum. The MacArthur Museum project has a target of $1.7 million to establish the displays. For many years there has been public interest in providing recognition of the presence in Brisbane of General Douglas MacArthur and the headquarters of Allied forces in the South-West Pacific area during 1942 to 1944, a crucial period in Australia's history. The MacArthur Museum project is a fine example of the kind of historically based, built-environment concept that deserves full support and whose proponents and backers deserve full credit.

Also tonight I want to say a few words about another aspect of Queensland's indelible connection with the events of the Pacific Warâthe Bakers Creek air crash in 1943, which killed 40 people and is still, 60 years later, Australia's worst air disaster. Because of wartime censorship the story of the crashâit was an accident, not resulting from enemy actionâwas to all intents and purposes suppressed. It was suppressed to the extent that the relatives of the deadâAmericansânever actually knew what had happened to their loved ones and even where they met their deaths.

In recent years the story of the tragic crash has been brought into public view, and strong links have been established between the RSL in Mackay and an American group formed in 2000, the Bakers Creek Memorial Association. The purpose of the association is to publicise the Bakers Creek air crash story in the United States; to assist the work of the Mackay RSL historian, Col Benson, to locate family relatives of the B-17C crash victims; and to raise funds to donate a scale model replica B-17C to the Bakers Creek Memorial near Mackay for the 60th anniversary commemoration.

The 60th anniversary went ahead as scheduled last weekend and I had the honour of meeting the American party here in Australia for that occasion in Brisbane last week. The `Bakers Creek Pilgrims' were led by Alvin `Mo' and Vera Berg, from Texas. I hope that the true Australian, true Queensland, hospitality we showed the participants will be a fond memory for them. There was a solemn purpose to the visit. On Saturday, 14 June a memorial was dedicated at the crash site and the scale model of the B17-C was placed on a plinth there. A report of the occasion and photographs can be viewed at www.ozatwar.com, a website operated by Peter Dunn. Among Americans also present were John B. `Skip' Hall Jr, a retired United States Air Force lieutenant general, who lives near Washington; Robert S. Cutler, professor, management of technology, at George Washington University; and Eileen A. Malloy, United States Consul General in Sydney. In the party, too, were Professor David Myers, publisher and founder of Central Queensland University Press; Mrs Jan Cardwell, manager, customer service at CQU Press; and Air Commodore Stewart Cameron of the RAAF, Commander Combat Support Group at Amberley near Ipswich. Once again we are reminded of the deep and abiding links between our country and America. These links are tremendously important and span the generations. They will endure. We shall all be grateful for that in the years to come.

subdebateinfo.title: Aviation: Karratha and Port Hedland Airports

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to talk about a quite serious problem that is faced by two of our great north-west cities in Western Australia, the cities of Karratha and Port Hedland. Last week I visited both centres. Both centres are thriving and there is a strong outlook for their local economies. The important element of both cities is that they are located in an area where Australia's great resource development projects are located. Karratha is the main residential dormitory centre for the North West Shelf, and all the offshore development associated with that, and for the Hamersley iron port of Dampier, which serves the inland mining towns of Paraburdoo and Tom Price. Port Hedland is the main centre for BHP's mining operation and serves the inland mining centre of Newman.

speech.para: Karratha and Port Hedland are the major export earners for resource earnings from foreign trade in Australia and they are quite sensitive from a national security point of view. Their link to the rest of Australia and the outside world is mostly through their airports, although they are served by road and by sea as well. But their airports are the key link. I discovered on my trip that, by virtue of a cynical cost-cutting decision by the federal government, the fire brigade services provided to the airports are to be terminated on 30 June.

Airservices Australia charged airlines a levy on a landed tonne basis to provide for the fire brigade services at the airports. As a result of a CASA regulation, inspired by the cost-cutting approach of this government, the threshold passenger load for each airport has been raised to 350,000 passengers, well beyond what the airports at Karratha and Port Hedland currently bear. Karratha has a passenger load factor of about 170,000 passenger movements a year and Port Hedland has a passenger load factor of 80,000 passenger movements per year at the present time, although I will say something about those figures in a moment. So putting the bar at 350,000 passengers means that the airlines will not collect the levy and, as a consequence, the dedicated firefighting facilities at both airports are to be terminated.

The only alternative now for any firefighting necessary at the airports is to call upon the town based volunteer fire services. People work for these fire services on a volunteer basis. I have great admiration for their dedication and for their skill. Their skill and training is about suburban and country firefighting. The extra level of skill necessary to deal with airport fires based around aviation movements is another matter. They would require extra training in order to bring themselves up to the necessary skill level to deal with airport fires. Those resources will have to be found from the local community.

At the Karratha airport the response time is about 90 seconds, according to an outstanding figure in the north-west of Western Australia, the President of the Roebourne Shire, Kevin Richards. The firefighting unit at the airport can respond to any fire on the premises within that time. If the airport has to obtain the fire service from the town of Karratha, which is located some distance from the airport, then it could take up to 45 minutes, since it is a volunteer service. The same is true if one applies those figures to the major centre of Port Hedland. If there is a fire disaster at either of the airports, there will be a much longer waitâa considerable waitâbefore there will be the ability to deal with and remedy that situation, and during that time any amount of devastation could be wreaked.

I said that at Karratha the annual passenger load factor was about 170,000 passengers. This is a centre where most of the fly-in, fly-out passengers come to serve on the offshore oil rigs. So now a key work force dealing with an international exporting venture like the North West Shelf is to land at an airport without a proper airport fire service. That is a concern in itself. Of course, I would prefer that the work force lived in Karratha, but the fly-in, fly-out situation is an option that the company has exercised.

The other thing is that, in determining what the passenger load factor might be for the airportâand the figure has been raised to 350,000âCASA does not consider helicopter movements. Rotary-wing movements are not counted for the sake of this figure; only fixed-wing movements are counted. Therefore, all of the passenger trafficâwhich is quite considerableâto the offshore oil rigs and to nearby Barrow Island by helicopter is not included for the sake of this calculation. Only a Canberra bureaucrat, not someone that lives in the north-west, could come up with that sort of grotesque calculation. Only someone not associated with the difficulties that north-west people find in moving around Australia could come up with that sort of calculation. Nonetheless, they haveâand, as a consequence, the funds are not going to be available.

I said that Port Hedland's passenger load factor at the present time was 80,000 passengers per year. That is quite a sizeable traffic. The Port Hedland council want to develop their own region and they see Port Hedland as a gateway to Australia from Bali and from nearby Indonesia. They are negotiating charter flights with Sempati Air and MerpatiâIndonesian airlinesâto bring passengers into Port Hedland. The fact that, from 30 June, because of cynical cost-cutting by this government, there will not be a full-time, fully trained emergency firefighting service on the ground at the airportârather than 45 minutes away in Port Hedlandâmeans that the cost of providing that service for international passengers as well as domestic passengers has to be met. For international passengers there has to be a fire service at the airport, which means making a special arrangement just for international flights.

Regional Australia deserves a break, and regional Australia ought to be given a break by this government. This government talks tough about what it is going to do to help regional Australia, but when you actually look at its performance there is very little there. By removing the fire service, it is inhibiting the ability of the town of Port Hedland to successfully conclude an international charter agreement with Indonesian airlines to bolster the regional economy. To not face up to the need to provide an airline service in the case of both Karratha and Port Hedland ignores the very sensitive national security issues for both of those centres, but it is also a brake on their development and means a higher cost and a levy for people living in the north-west of Western Australia.

With this government I always say, `Don't listen to what they say; watch what they do.' In watching what they do here, we see a clear case of a particular penalty being applied to those Australians who perform the role of developing this wonderful country of ours, living in remote areas of Australia and working to develop Australia. Robyn Crane, who is the acting chief executive officer of the Pilbara Development Commission, said to me just last week, `I can't understand how the federal government can sanction not having firefighters at Karratha Airport.' Barry Haase, the member for Kalgoorlie, spent $416,000 on postage prior to the last election. If that money had been spent on providing airport fire services, those two airports would have a fire service now able to meet the needs of the local community and give the reassurance necessary for passengers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to congratulate members of the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union and its sister union in the United States, the Service Employees International Union, on their campaign demanding decent wages and conditions for cleaners employed in the more than 120 Westfield shopping centres around the world.

speech.para: Yesterday, on 16 June, cleaners around the world celebrated International Justice for Cleaners Day, or Justice for Janitors Day, as it is known in the US. This day commemorates the struggle of cleaners in Los Angeles who were attacked by police in 1990 during a peaceful demonstration against a cleaning contractor. Community outrage after this incident led to the formation of union locals that, over the many years of the Justice for Janitors campaign, have been highly successful in achieving improvements in wages, conditions, health care and job security. The leadership and rank and file of the SEIU are to be commended for their tenacious efforts in achieving these improvements.

The Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union is marking International Justice for Cleaners Day by launching a campaign calling on Westfield chairman Frank Lowy to agree to minimum standards in the awarding of cleaning contracts, which include abiding by award conditions, ensuring basic occupational health and safety standards are met and guaranteeing that companies who are awarded cleaning contracts are meeting their commitments, such as workers compensation premiums, superannuation payments and appropriate taxes. I hope this campaign is successful, and I find it hard to imagine that, when it is put to him, Frank Lowy, the CEO of Westfield, will disagree with it.

Cleaners in our shopping centres are an invisible force. Multinational giants like Westfield rely on these workers being efficient and reliable and maintaining an environment that allows the company to charge topnotch rents. In return, shopping centre cleaners are amongst the most exploited workers in the Australian community. According to the ABS, over 95,000 workers are employed in the cleaning industry in Australia, including over 8,600 in my home state of South Australia. This industry is dominated by women and includes many workers from non-English-speaking backgrounds. Only 22 per cent of workers in this industry enjoy full-time employment, with the other 78 per cent employed on part-time or casual bases. Even taking into account the most recent living wage increase, which we note the government opposed, cleaners earn the princely sum of $12.38 an hour. Many of them do not work many hours a week. Make no mistake, on these wages and with the hours worked, many cleaners in Australia are working and living in poverty. Those senators involved in the Senate poverty inquiry would have heard horrific stories of the day-to-day struggle to live in dignity that workers like these have to endure. This is also the section of the community that the Howard government has in its crosshairs in its plan to destroy Medicare and make higher education the preserve of the wealthy.

Prior to entering the parliament I had the privilege of representing some of these workers in legal disputes, often surrounding unfair dismissal or a failure to pay correct entitlements. From this experience I have seen companies like Westfield adopting an aggressive policy of increasing profits by awarding contracts solely on price, creating a downward spiral where cleaning contractors inevitably make their own profits off the backs of low-paid workers.

Like many of the workers who clean his shopping towns, Mr Lowy came to Australia as a migrant with little other than a determination to work for a better future for himself and his family. That spirit, displayed by many migrants into Australia, has helped build the country we know and love, yet increasingly that spirit is not being rewarded with the opportunities it deserves. Cleaners are often caught in poverty cycles, not being able to afford basic health and education. No doubt, Westfield will argue that the wages and conditions of cleaners have nothing to do with the owners of the shopping mall because it is the contractors who are the employers, but it is Westfield who selects the contractor and in these shopping centres the contractor acts in the name of Westfield. It is Westfield who selects the contractors on the basis of price, pushing wages and conditions downwards. Westfield has a responsibility to ensure workers are treated decently and that contractors are meeting their minimum legal obligations.

It seems inconceivable that Mr Lowy, when presented with these facts through this campaign, would do anything other than immediately take steps to rectify the problems occurring on his property. It would seem inconceivable that Mr Lowy, whose story epitomises the migrant's dream and who is now amongst the richest people in Australia, would want to treat others worse than he was treated. Mr Lowy is one of the success stories of our post-war immigration policy, arriving from Europe in 1952 with no capital and poor English skillsâan identical situation to that of many of Australia's cleaners. However, in those days Australia enjoyed a centralised wage system that acted as a genuine safety net, a springboard where new migrants like Mr Lowy were able to earn a decent wage and participate not only in the economy but also in the society more broadly.

In 1950 the pay differential between average wages and the salaries of CEOs was about one to five. Over the past six years the Howard government has torn the industrial safety net to shreds. Rising wealth inequality and ballooning executive salaries have seen this differential grow to a point where CEOs earn on average 400 times more than a cleaner in a Westfield shopping centre. This divide has been further compounded by an attack on essential public services, health and education. I congratulate LHMU members on their efforts in this campaign. I join with them in calling for Westfield to sit down with the relevant unions to negotiate a global protocol on service sector tendering. The fact that a service is contracted out is not an excuse for minimum wages and conditions to be avoided.

talk.start.para: âI begin my remarks by making a short reference to the comments of Senator Cook, who is no longer in the chamber. In his speech he made reference to a Canberra bureaucrat having been responsible for some decision of which he disapproved. First of all, I do not know whether the bureaucrat of whom he complains was a Canberra bureaucrat or perhaps a Perth bureaucrat, but I would hope that a former minister of the Crown in this country would acknowledge that he has had many Canberra bureaucrats provide him with dedicated and loyal service and would be a little less likely as a result to refer in that disparaging way to bureaucrats who happen to live in Canberra. I hope that he is listening to these remarks and is taking note.

speech.para: My comments this evening are not, however, about Senator Cook but about the work of Greening Australia. In 1982, the International Year of the Tree, a small community based group called Greening Australia was formed to raise concerns about tree loss and to organise the mass planting of trees. I am not sure whether Bob Hawke's prediction of planting one billion trees before 2000 came to fruition, but if it did Greening Australia can take a large part of the credit.

Just last month I attended the 21st anniversary celebrations of that organisation, and I think it is fair to say that Greening Australia has been one of Australia's great environmental successes. Today it is an organisation with some 300 staff and a national role focusing on issues such as water quality and salinity, biodiversity and community capacity building. It has formed constructive partnerships with government, fellow environmental groups and industry.

I have to say that I see some environmental organisations in the community which appear to be more interested in environmental politics than the environment. Those organisations attract little respect from people like me. I have great respect for Greening Australia because it gets on with the job of protecting and enhancing the Australian environment.

Greening Australia is an organisation that is particularly well respected in the bush capital, and it has been an important part of the ACT's environmental recovery following the 18 January firestorms. Greening Australia is rare among environmental organisations. It enjoys universal support, is non-political and, most importantly, achieves tangible benefits for the environment. In 2001-02 Greening Australia planted over two million seedlings, collected 2,400 kilos of native seed, conserved almost 180,000 hectares of native vegetation, erected over 3,500 kilometres of fencing to conserve native vegetation and trained and educated 19,418 peopleâan impressive achievement.

Of course, statistics have a limited impact on the public imagination. It is only when you see the results of Greening Australia's work that you begin to understand the magnitude of its contribution. For example, Greening Australia has been part of the Saltshaker project in the Boorowa catchment, north-west of Canberra. It has tackled salinity in more than 200 sites in the catchment. One farmer commented on this by saying, `Saltshaker has been fantastic. In this paddock I had three trees. Now I have got 3,500.'

This project was funded through the Howard government's $2.7 billion Natural Heritage Trust, the largest environmental rescue effort ever delivered by an Australian government. In the 2001 budget the government announced an extra $1 billion for the trust, which extends funding through till 2006. Another Greening Australia initiative that has been funded by the Natural Heritage Trust has been the Bidgee Banks project, which has tackled erosion in key areas in the mid and upper Murrumbidgee catchments. This project has particular significance for the people of the ACT. Like countless other Greening Australia projects, this project was successful because it encouraged participation from all stakeholders, not just Landcare groups. It won a Banksia award last year, which is a significant achievement in environmental circles.

I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge some recent Natural Heritage Trust backed projects in the ACT region, some of which Greening Australia has been involved with. The Gudgenby Bush Regeneration project continues the re-establishment of native vegetation close to the Namadgi National Park. The Creel and Recall Survey for Lake Ginninderra undertook an independent survey of recreational fishing in Lake Ginninderra. The Waterwatch Resource Centre in the Tuggeranong Valley is a project where staff and students from Lake Tuggeranong College monitored water quality and initiated awareness raising projects due to rapid expansion of Tuggeranong and its accompanying young school-aged population. The Vegetation Investment Project will enlarge key vegetation patches and establish 240 hectares of links between remnant vegetation in the southern ACT region. The Waterwatch program in the Ginninderra catchment aims to improve water quality in the catchment. The upstream urban stormwater in Ginninderra Creek flows into the Murrumbidgee River and the severely degraded Murray-Darling system, which gives the project extra significance. Ten schools and five Landcare groups have been involved in this project.

In 2002, a three-year, $69 million contract was awarded jointly to Greening Australia and Job Futures to run the Green Corps program. It shows that Greening Australia is not only a body with environmental expertise but also one which has some financial nous. About 85 per cent of Green Corps projects are located in rural and regional Australia. This is justified not only because of the environmental problems facing non-urban Australia but also because of the comparative lack of work experience opportunities for young people in these areas. Nevertheless, the ACT will soon benefit from a Green Corps project that will assist in recovery from the bushfires in the upper Murrumbidgee catchment. In conjunction with the ACT Rural Lessees Association, this project will assist farmers with refencing, vegetation surveys to determine more fire resistant species, seed collection, combating erosion, and carrying out water quality testing. The young ACT residents who participate in this project will also learn occupational health and safety procedures and basic first aid and will gain career guidance.

This speech has predominantly sung the praises of Greening Australia. I hope it has also given the Senate further evidence of the national importance and professionalism of this organisation. Apart from immediate challenges, such as its involvement in the Green Corps and the Natural Heritage Trust, Greening Australia sees its greatest medium-term challenge as developing more effective partnerships between governments, business and the community. I wish them well in this. It is this type of partnership that can provide Australia with a secure economic and environmental future. I want to thank the many staff and volunteers of Greening Australia who, through their actions, have made a practical expression of their commitment to the environment over many years.

talk.start.para: âOn 6 August this year it will be Hiroshima Day, 58 years after the first dropping of an atomic bomb in 1945. To mark that anniversary, the Democrats are calling on the government to use its influence on the world stage to do two things: firstly, to push for a global ban on weapons containing depleted uranium; and, secondly, to urge the United States to not go on with its nuclear Star Wars program. I will come to that issue later this week but first I want to talk about depleted uraniumâDU.

speech.para: Thirteen years after Australia stopped using depleted uranium in ammunitions, Australian troops sent to Iraqâas well as Iraq's civilian populationâwere exposed to DU used there by allied forces. We think it is time that our defence forces put DU weapons in the same category as cluster bombs. We do not use them and we do not support their use by the United States, the United Kingdom or anyone else, for that matter, and for very good reasons. Australia has a worthy history of opposing the use of landminesâindeed, our technical forces have been very active in de-mining many countries around the world. That has not been enough, of course, as there are still more landmines being planted than we can de-mine, but their efforts have, no doubt, saved lives on many occasions.

We could add to that history by urging that depleted uranium weapons are explicitly included in non-proliferation treaties. The Australian government used depleted uranium in weapons from 1981, and the Democrats first questioned the government about this in parliament more than 20 years ago. Thankfully, Australia stopped using DU ammunition in 1990, acknowledging that this was for health and safety reasons. We know it is highly likely that DU is at least a contributing factor in Gulf War syndrome. The use of DU munitions raises major concerns not just about the effects on all combatants but also about the long-term health of civilian populations which live in the affected areas well after the conflict is over.

DU is used in weapons because it is heavy, it is hard and it is very cheap. What is more, it is an intractable waste product, which makes getting rid of it in other countries a highly attractive proposition for those who have it. But there are alternatives to DU, such as tungsten, which is more effective and safer but, of course, much more expensive. DU is pyrophoricâin other words, it ignites and burns upon hitting a hard target. When DU weapons hit a target, a fine aerosol of uranium oxides is emitted. Most are small enough to be readily inhaled by humans, and the very smallest can lodge deep in the lungs. Once released, these fine particles can be spread by the wind or by vehicle and personnel movements.

Two months ago I wrote to the Minister for Defence asking for Australian troops to be blood tested for chromosomal aberration as a result of DU exposure. The United Kingdom has announced that British troops are to be offered DU testing. This comes after the UK's Royal Society were asked to look at the impact of depleted uraniumâa source of radiationâon health. The Royal Society basically said that more research was required. They said that we need to be cognisant of depleted uranium and we need to administer the survey tool to our people to identify those who might have been exposed. So the UK government has gone ahead with this, and I think it is reasonable for us to ask the Australian government to do likewise.

At the budget estimates hearings for the Department of Defence of 4 June this year, Senator Bartlett questioned officers and officials, General Cosgrove and Defence Minister Hill about a number of issues, including exposure to DU. General Cosgrove provided the sorts of answers that we are accustomed to from government ministersâin other words: `Trust us. We trust the United States government.' He said:

quote.para: I am quite confident that the way we employed our people would not have led them into exposure of any significance to DU effects.

speech.para: We were told in estimates that Australia was waiting on US data about where environmental threats such as DU existed, and Defence will assess that data against Australian troop deployments. If they may have been exposed, there will be urinary DU screening. The people of Iraq of course do not have access to these maps showing where there was risk of DU exposure, and few of them will be able to access urinary DU screening.

A Defence officer told us that Australia had piggybacked on the US led coalition's `robust' efforts to put environmental people on the ground to conduct routine soil, water and air sampling. They are linking that with geospatial data so they are able to identify what environmental threats were at play in that location, even down to things like overlaying satellite imagery to show the presence or absence of oil fire smoke plumes. We will have access to that data for our deployed personnel, where the Americans did the monitoring. Apparently, we are in the process of acquiring that data from the United States. It will certainly make for a very interesting map of the environmental hazards in Iraq not just for our troops but for the Iraqi population.

Dr Doug Rokke, an expert on the use of depleted uranium in US armaments, is presently touring Australia. Dr Rokke was also a major in the United States armed services, was a military physicist in charge of the clean-up in Kuwait, has since become an outspoken opponent of the use of DU weapons and is a strong advocate of clean-ups in the name of human and health rights. He knows only too well that these weapons can do great harm. He and his team of 100 men brought out some of the tanks and other vehicles that had been hit by DU weapons in the first Gulf War. Thirty of his team have since died, and Dr Rokke himself is ill.

In the first Gulf War, soldiers were told there were no adverse health effects from DU. Subsequently Dr Rokke did studies of Gulf War veterans, who now in their many thousands have cancer related illnesses. He has also done work on the effects of the first Gulf War on the health of people from southern Iraq and Kuwait, and more recently he has done similar work in Afghanistan. There was a lot more depleted uranium used in the recent Gulf War, much of it in civilian areas.

Dr Rokke's tour has been organised by Australian peace groups. If members of the public would like to hear him speak, he will be addressing a public meeting at the Melbourne Town Hall on the evening of Tuesday, 24 June; at the University of Tasmania on the evening of Friday, 27 June; at Sydney University on Tuesday, 1 July; at Fremantle Town Hall on the afternoon of Saturday, 5 July; and in Adelaide on Thursday, 10 July. He will be speaking tomorrow night at the Brisbane Town Hall. I will be meeting Dr Rokke in Melbourne and I would encourage government MPs and others in this chamber to do likewise. I am sure what he has to say will be of great interest to people in this place.

talk.start.para: âI was saddened to learn of the passing of a wonderful person, the Hon. William Charles Wentworth. So much of Bill's life was devoted to the service of the people of Australia that his passing marks a notable point in our history of the period during which he was such a remarkable contributor. While I started my parliamentary career just as Bill was finishing his, we nevertheless became good friends through regular correspondence and meetings on a range of economic issues we had in common, such as the need for budget surpluses, the concerns of current account deficits, the plight of manufacturing in Australia and tariffs, to name but a few. I believe we both enjoyed the opportunity to debate these issues, even if sometimes it was only with each other. My problem was always how to singly deliver what Bill wanted, a frustration for Bill and an embarrassment for me.

speech.para: Bill's brilliance could be seen in his views, which were certainly well ahead of his time and the conventional thinking of the period. Born in Sydney to a historical family that included colonial explorers and newspaper proprietors, he was educated at the Armidale School and later obtained his Master of Arts at New College in Oxford. Upon returning home, he was an economic adviser to the New South Wales Treasury from 1933 to 1936.

In fact a lot of people remember Bill from his exploits with the Army Reserveâexploits that at the time were unconventional but certainly very effective. How he managed to avoid being court-marshalled is testimony to the message of his campaigns about the hopeless state of the adequacy of Australia's defences at the time, particularly around the large cities. In 1941 he enlisted with the Army Reserve and rose to the rank of captain, 1st Division Headquarters. It was here that he displayed the rebellious streak that I am referring to. On one occasion he led a party that captured the Waterfall police station to demonstrate the inadequacies of home defence. There is mythology surrounding some of the other exploits.

Bill was elected on 12 occasions to the federal parliament. As one of the forty-niners, in 1949 he was elected to represent the people of Mackellar and held the seat for 28 years. He has been described variously as an occupational rebel, even within his own party. Perhaps this rebellious streak was something that endeared him to so many Australians. As a critic of the Menzies government, he was not appointed to a ministry until the election of John Gorton as Prime Minister in 1968. Bill served as the first person to be specifically responsible for Aboriginal affairs, and this is certainly a historic achievement. He deserves special credit for his important achievements during his tenureâvery brief; only three years as minister. In promoting the recognition of Aboriginal people, he persuaded Menzies to agree to the important referendum that included Aborigines in the census, which was finally held under Prime Minister Holt in 1967.

Bill was absolutely passionate about equal rights for Indigenous Australiansâa view not strongly held at the time. He strongly supported moves towards granting land rights and steering policy from outright assimilation in favour of integration. On this note, an example of the unwillingness of the people of his era to treat him seriously was when Bill was completely left out when the Labor government celebrated the referendum's 25th anniversary in 1992.

Another storyâas his nephew Mungo McCallum, a journalist in this place, recallsâoccurred when the ceremony to celebrate the standardisation of railway was held. Bill was not invited to attend, despite his strong advocacy for decades about the need for standardisation of the Melbourne-Sydney gauge. As the determined driving force behind this issue he was obviously very hurt, but his wife came to the rescue. She appeared on the platform bearing a placard which demanded, `Where's Wentworth?' Its publication in many newspapers no doubt got the point across, such was the unconventional nature of the Wentworth family.

Regardless of the topic of discussion, Bill was passionate, independent and vigorous in debate. Many members of parliament have recalled Bill as a very colourful person during their tributes this week. Mrs Bronwyn Bishop recalled Bill's passion for economics and mathematics, with him mentioning to her once that he was engaged in correspondence with a particular professor concerning the method of calculating infinity. Perhaps that is an indication of his life at Oxford, looking at philosophical issues.
According to the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, in the other place yesterday, Ian Sinclair was in cabinet when Bill was a minister from 1968 to 1972 and Ian remembers:

quote.para: ... Bill Wentworth had a thousand solutions to every problemâforty or fifty of which would be quite brilliant.

speech.para: Ian also recalls that `Bill Wentworth insisted on personally writing his own cabinet submissions', which were `discursive, wide-ranging and idiosyncraticâsomething of a reflection of their author'. Many people say that Bill inherited many of his qualitiesâincluding a strong will, passion and independenceâfrom his great-grandfather, William Wentworth, who was amongst the first colonial explorers to cross the Blue Mountains.

In hindsight, perhaps Bill's major error was in breaking away from the Liberal Party for a time. No doubt it was a reflection of the fact that many Liberal Party leaders in his era really had difficulty in coping with his exceptional brilliance. They found it hard to accommodate so many of his views or even to harness some of his extraordinary energiesâwith the exception perhaps of the late John Gorton when he was Prime Minister. Bill's propensity to debate issues was a highlight of his career. He rarely stepped back from issues he thought needed airing and his contribution to the nation, especially through his Aboriginal affairs work, was remarkable for its vision. He carried on with this work with Aborigines well after he left parliament and into his later life.

The late William Charles Wentworth was a fantastic Australian, a great parliamentarian and a brilliant man. I consider it my great fortune to have counted him as a friend. It is with great sympathy that I offer my condolences to his wife, Barbara, who was a great help to him, and to his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren in their loss. Bill, we salute you.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 13 November 2002:

quote.para: With reference to page 95 of the Department Annual Report for 2001-2002:
(1) What contribution did the department make to the development and implementation of the joint government/industry strategy to influence the development of the United States Farm Bill.
(2) What are the details of the strategy
(3) What assessment has been made of the success of the strategy.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) made a major contribution to developing and implementing a strategy to attempt to influence the US Farm Bill. This was done in close cooperation with the Commonwealth Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), the Australian Embassy in Washington, and a wide cross section of Australian agricultural industry. Core elements of the strategy were developed through the Agricultural Trade Consultative Group (ATCG), which is co-chaired by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, The Hon Warren Truss MP and the Minister for Trade, The Hon Mark Vaile MP, and through its Steering Group, which met frequently and is chaired at Deputy Secretary level.
(2) Details of the strategy included
Research and Analysis
Â· Closely monitoring the debate and policy process in the United States (US) in conjunction with DFAT and the Australian Embassy in Washington;

Â· Developing common messages associated with the Farm Bill which were used to put Australia's case in Washington by both Government and industry. This included Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) research and publications which showed, amongst other things, the deleterious implications of the proposed Farm Bill on the domestic US economy and on international agricultural markets, and World Trade Organisation (WTO) negotiating environment; and
Â· Identifying key players in Congress and the Administration with potential to influence the US legislative processes as the focus of our lobbying efforts;
Communication of Messages
Â· Meeting regularly with key industry representatives to assess the situation and respond to developments in Washington;
Â· Delivering Australia's messages in a coordinated and timely manner in conjunction with industry;
Â· Reinforcing to the Administration and key Congressional figures the links between a protectionist Farm Bill and US leadership credibility in the WTO Doha round of agriculture negotiations; and
Â· Producing, in consultation with DFAT, âFarm Bill Newslettersâ to ensure that the key stakeholders were kept informed of the latest US Farm Bill developments.
Mechanisms
Â· Regular consultations in Washington with local agents of Australian agricultural industry;
Â· Encouraging other Cairns Group countries to make similar representations about the Farm Bill; and

Â· Assistance to Ministers, including letter to counterparts and planning and implementation of a government/industry delegation led by the Hon Warren Truss MP to Washington to lobby Congress and the Administration.

(3) Two important objectives were achieved in that the duration of the Bill was limited to 6 rather than 10 years and built-in constraints were included in the Bill to ensure that certain program spending does not breach US WTO commitments. Feedback has been received that the strategy successfully placed Australia's concerns about the Farm Bill in the minds of US policy-makers.

During Minister Truss' visit to the US in December 2001 to lobby US Administration, key Australian industry representatives provided positive comments supporting his efforts. Industry's support for the initiative was also reflected in a letter to the Office of the Prime Minister dated 24 September 2001 in which the National Farmers' Federation indicated it fully supported high level government representation in Washington to lobby key members of the US House of Representatives.

subdebateinfo.title: Transport and Regional Services: Farm Management Deposit Scheme
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 955)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 21 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) On what date did the department first become aware that some Farm Management Deposit (FMD) products may not comply with legislation applicable to the Governments FMD scheme.
(2) (a) What was the source of this information; and (b) in what form was this information conveyed, for example, correspondence, e-mail, telephone conversation or direct conversation.
(3) What was the nature of the problem specifically identified in this information.
(4) On what date did the department inform the Minister, or his office, of this problem.

(5) Did the Minister, or his office, receive advice about this problem from a source other than the Minister's department; if so: (a) on what date was this information first received; (b) what was the source of this information; (c) in what form was this information conveyed; and (d) what was the nature of the problem specifically identified in this information.
(6) (a) On what date, or dates, did the department take action in response to this identified problem; and (b) what action did the department take.

(7) (a) What departments, agencies, banks or non-bank financial institutions did the department communicate with in relation to this matter; (b) on what date, or dates, did that communication occur; and (c) what form did that communication take.
(8) (a) What responses, if any, has the department received in respect to those communications; (b) in what form have those responses been received; and (c) what was the content of those responses.
(9) What action has the department taken in response to communications from departments, agencies, banks or non-bank financial institutions.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The issue lies outside the Department of Transport and Regional Services area of responsibility. Department has no formal advice or knowledge regarding the assertions.
(2) to (4) Not applicable - see (1).
(5) My office has no record of the matter being raised with my staff or me.
(6) to (9) Not applicable - see (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Australian National Residue Survey
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 994)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 5 December 2002:

quote.para: For each of the 110 cases referred to on page 1 of the report for 2001-02 on the results of the Australian National Residue Survey Results, where residues were above Australian Standards, can details be provided of:
(a) the level of residue;
(b) the State and place where the measurement occurred; and
(c) the penalty which resulted

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator Troeth
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: There were 61 residue contraventions reported by the National Residue Survey (NRS) on page one, in the NRS Results Report 2001-2002. Of the 61 residues in excess of Australian Standards, 47 residues were of agricultural and veterinary (agvet) chemicals and 14 were of metals.
A contravention (i.e. a level above the Australian Standard) is recorded in the following instances:
1. The residue recorded is above the Australian Standard that is set.

2. There is a residue recorded but there is no Australian standard for an agvet chemical, as it is not set. In this case residues have been detected for inedible materials such as urine, faeces. This testing is based on some residues not being readily detected in edible tissues but can be detected in inedible tissues.
3. There is no Australian Standard set, and a residue level is detected in an edible tissue.
Details of (a) the level of the residue recorded and (b) the State where the measurement occurred and (c) the penalty, which resulted, are tabulated in the attached table.

State/Territory agricultural departments conduct the traceback investigations of residues above the Australian Standard and are responsible for any corrective actions including imposition of penalties (if applicable). The National Residue Survey receives notification from the States/Territories on the outcomes of these investigations.
Contraventions of Australian Standards
Report on the Australian National Residue Survey Results 2001-2002

entry.para: -zearalanol (zeranol). Investigation by State department indicated residues occur from natural ingestion of Fusarium (fungus) infected pasture. Non-treatable, non-threatening occurrence. No penalty.
Boldenone. Investigation by State department indicated metabolite of normal sex hormones. Non-treatable, non-threatening occurrence. No penalty.
Dihydrostreptomycin. Warning letter sent to the producer by State department.
Neomycin. Withholding-period was observed. Australian Pesticides & Veterinary Medicines Authority is reviewing the Australian Standard.
19-nortestosterone ( and ). Investigations by State departments indicated metabolite of normal sex hormones Non-treatable, non-threatening occurrence. No penalty.
Boldenone. Investigation by State department indicated metabolite of natural sex hormones. Non-treatable, non-threatening occurrence. No penalty.

Cadmium. A common environmental contaminant of soils of southern Australia (SA, WA and VIC). Four residue levels lower than agreed residue action level for a traceback investigation. For the other residue traceback undertaken by State department, but source of sample not identifiable by abattoir that collected the sample. No further action.
Lead. Traceback by State departments could not identify point source. No further action.

Sulphadimidine (methazine). Traceback by State department determined accidental exposure of finisher pigs to medicated feed. Warning letter has been sent to the owner by State department and work practices implemented to prevent the incident from reoccurring.
19-nortestosterone ( and ). Traceback by State department identified metabolite of normal sex hormones. Non-treatable, non-threatening occurrence. No penalty.
Lead. Traceback by State department could not identify point source. Additional bulked liver samples to be taken from birds at the next slaughter.
19-nortestosterone ( and ). Investigation by Territory department indicated metabolite of normal sex hormones. Non-treatable, non-threatening occurrence. No penalty.

Moxidectin. State department investigation identified off-label use of a product registered for sheep. Producers realised `off-label' use but unaware of implications. Producers made aware of implications. State did not advise specific penalty. Industry to lobby for registration of suitable worming treatment for goats.
Lead. State department traceback investigation did not determine the source. No further action.

Mercury. Investigations have not resulted in any penalties being applied by State/Territory departments. Residue management strategies, of which this is part, prevent catch being taken from areas known to have high levels of environmental contaminants or limit fish size caught.

Chlorpyrifos. One traceback by State department indicated an off-label use of the chemical to treat the base of a storage silo. Warning letter and advice sent to grower by State department. The other traceback was inconclusive. No further action taken.

Dichlorvos.1 Traceback by State departments indicated that incomplete label directions and subsequent failure to observe withholding period contributed to the contraventions. States have not reported a penalty.
Dichlorvos.1 Traceback by State department indicated that label directions were not followed correctly. Each grower received an advisory letter from State department.

Dichlorvos.1 Traceback by State department identified three residues as a result of communication and record keeping problems. Grain stores involved are implementing training, recording and stock management practices. The other residue detection received from the State department a warning letter, and a copy of State record keeping requirements.

Chlorpyrifos-methyl. Traceback by State department indicated mechanical breakdown when auguring the grain into a storage silo resulted in over-treatment of the grain. Management advice sent to the grower.

Dichlorvos.1 Traceback by State department indicated incomplete label directions and subsequent failure to observe the withholding period caused residue detection above Australian Standards. State department has not advised any penalty.

Malathion. Traceback by State department identified that chemical could have been used as a hygiene treatment around the base of the silos and cross contamination of the lupins may have occurred. As chemical treatment unconfirmed no further action required.
Fenitrothion. Traceback by State department could not conclusively identify the cause of the residue. No further action.
Chlorpyrifos-methyl. Traceback by State department could not conclusively identify the cause of the residue. No further action.

Fenitrothion.Traceback by State department could not conclusively identify the cause of the residue in one case. In other two cases letter written by State department to all contributing growers to silo regarding the residues found. No further action.

Diphenylamine. Traceback by State department indicated five residues above the Australian Standard because the fruit packer followed directions based on a consultant's advice rather than the label directions. Packer will use chemical at label rates in future. No penalty applied. One residue above the Australian Standard due to over application of chemical as equipment was not correctly calibrated. Grower received warning letter from State Department. One residue above the Australian Standard was due to the product label not specifying a lower rate for the particular variety of apple when held in an ultra-low oxygen storage. Grower will use a lower rate in future. No further action.
Iprodione. Traceback by State department unable to identify cause, as label directions were followed carefully. No further action.

quote.para: 1 Australian Pesticides & Veterinary Medicines Authority is currently conducting a review of dichlorvos, in liaison with the NRS and other stakeholders.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 19 December 2002:

quote.para: With reference to Australian beef exports to Japan:

(1) (a) What discussions has the Minister undertaken with Japanese officials during 2002 in relation to Australian beef imports to Japan known as `Aussie Beef'; (b) who attended each meeting; (c) when did each meeting occur; (d) what was discussed at each meeting; and (e) what records were kept of each meeting.

(2) (a) What discussions has the Minister had with Japanese officials specifically in relation to the import restrictions known as the `snap-back'; (b) who attended each meeting; (c) when did each meeting occur; (d) what was discussed at each meeting; and (e) what records were kept of each meeting.
(3) Is the `snap-back' calculated on total beef imports into Japan, or on a country-by-country basis.
(4) Will the `snap-back' be invoked on Australian beef imports to Japan during the 2002-03 and 2003-04 financial years.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) The Minister had the following meetings in 2002 with Japanese officials where Australian beef exports to Japan were discussed
(i) (b) Mr Tsutomu Takebe, Japanese Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries;
Mr Takehiko Endoh, Senior Vice Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries;
Mr Yoshiharu Takenaka, Vice Minister for International Affairs, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries;
Mr Hidenori Murakami, Director General, International Affairs Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries; and
Mr Masayuki Araki, Director, International Policy Planning Division, General Food Policy Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries.
(i) (c) Tuesday 29 January 2002

(i) (d) Issues discussed at this meeting included the postponed Quint meeting, Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) and its effect on Australian beef sales to Japan, fisheries, Japanese agricultural policy, rice and Australian exports to Japan.
(i) (e) There is a cable reporting on this meeting.
(ii) (b) Mr Chikara Sakaguchi, Minister for Health, Labour and Welfare;
Dr Shinpei Ozaki, Director General, Department of Food Sanitation, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare; and
Dr Satoshi Takaya, Director, Inspection and Safety Division, Department of Food Sanitation, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
(ii) (c) Wednesday 30 January 2002
(ii) (d) Issues discussed at this meeting included BSE, and the safety of Australian beef.
(ii) (e) There is a cable reporting on this meeting.
(iii) (b) Mr Koyo Nishikawa, Deputy Chairman Liberal Democratic Party Diet Affairs Committee, Member of the House of Representatives; and
Mr Masahiro Imamura, Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs.
(iii) (c) Wednesday 30 January 2002
(iii) (d) Issues discussed at this meeting included the Doha Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, Japan's agricultural policy, BSE and Australian beef exports to Japan
(iii) (e) There is no written record of this meeting as it was a luncheon meeting
(iv) (b) Mr Takehiko Endoh, Senior Vice Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries
Mr Eiji Ishigaki, Secretary to the Senior Vice Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries

Mr Masayuki Araki, Director, International Policy Planning Division, General Food Policy Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Mr Hiroyuki Nishiura, Deputy Director, International Economic Affairs Division, General Policy Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries
Mr Akihiro Mae, Deputy Director, Far Seas Fisheries Division, Resources Management Department, Japanese Fisheries Agency

Mr Yuichi Nakamura, Chief, International Policy Planning Division, General Food Policy Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Mr Tetsuya Tamai, Counsellor Agriculture, Japanese Embassy
(iv) (c) Saturday 28 April 2002

(iv) (d) Issues discussed at this meeting include the Japanese beef market following BSE, the safety of Australian beef, the proposed new Japanese Food Safety Agency, the Japanese Prime Minister's forthcoming visit to Australia, and the World Trade Organisation (WTO) negotiations.
(iv) (e) There is a record of this meeting.
(2) (a) The Minister had the following meeting in 2002 with Japanese officials where the issue of `snap-back' was discussed
(b) Mr Tsutomu Takebe, Japanese Minister of Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry;
Mr Yoshiharu Takenaka, Vice Minister for International Affairs, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries; and
Mr Hidenori Murakami, Director General, International Affairs Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries.
(c) Thursday 25 July 2002

(d) Issues discussed at this meeting included the possible triggering of the WTO safeguards (`snap-back') provisions for Japanese beef imports, Japanese agricultural policies and the proposed new Japanese Food Safety Agency.
(e) There is a cable reporting on this meeting.
(3) The `snap-back' is calculated on total beef imports into Japan. Separate and identical `snap-back' mechanisms apply for chilled and frozen beef.
(4) Minister Truss and the Trade Minister will be negotiating with the Japanese Government with a view to removing the `snap-back' provision.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 25 February 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Commonwealth commitment of $2.65 million to the Murrumbidgee Valley Water Efficiency Feasibility Project:
(1) When will this funding be expended.
(2) Will the Commonwealth provide other resources to the project; if so, can details be provided.
(3) Is it the case that the New South Wales Government will make a contribution of $2.65 million to the project.
(4) What contribution of funding and resources will Pratt Water make to the project.

(5) Is it the case that the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation, Mr Aquilina, announced the project funding arrangements, including the Commonwealth contribution, on 19 December 2002.
(6) Why did the Minister re-announce the project on 11 February 2003.
(7) How will the project complement the Commonwealth's `broader discussions and on water property rights.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Funding will be expended once contractual arrangements are finalised and upon approval by the Commonwealth/New South Wales (NSW) Natural Resource Management (NRM) Steering Committee of individual project plans for each phase of the study.
(2) No additional resources have been allocated to the project. However, the Commonwealth may provide information to the project from existing sources.
(3) The Commonwealth and NSW governments are each providing matching funding of up to $2.65 million to the project.

(4) Pratt Water, which fully funded the Pratt Water report, âWater in the Murrumbidgee Valleyâ, is to provide and bear the cost of 8 dedicated full time officers plus associated support for office accommodation, IT network and general corporate services.
(5) On the 19 and 20 December, NSW and the Commonwealth ministers put out media releases announcing the two government's joint commitment to fund the feasibility study.

(6) On 11 February the Federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, the Hon Warren Truss MP, and the Federal Minister for Environment and Heritage, the Hon David Kemp MP, the Federal Member of Riverina, Mrs Kay Hull MP and Mr Richard Pratt provided a joint media release on progress of the project.
(7) The project will complement the Commonwealth's broader discussions on water by:

Â· preparing a full feasibility or `business case' for future investment by public and private investors in water savings within the case study area - the Murrumbidgee River System in southern NSW; and

Â· as a pilot study, providing lessons and analysis that may be applied more broadly in considering water savings investments in other areas of NSW and in developing a national approach to water savings.

Senator Ian Macdonald

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 25 February 2003:

quote.para: In relation to discretionary payment right determinations under the Supplementary Dairy Assistance (SDA) scheme:
(1) Can details be provided of matters taken into account when determining whether an eligible dairy leasing arrangement exists.

(2) Which specific matters, including but not limited to the assessment of dairy leasing arrangements, were taken into account in relation to assessment of SDA applications from Fiona Wilson, Leanne Berboon and Phillip Stoll.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Under the Supplementary Dairy Assistance Scheme (SDA) the matters taken into account to determine whether an eligible dairy leasing arrangement exists are those defined in the Diary Structural Adjustment Program (DSAP) scheme.
Factors taken into account in making this assessment are:
a. Whether quota was required for the delivery of market milk by the enterprise in 1998/99.
b. If quota was required, whether the owner of quota used by the enterprise leased some or all of the quota.
c. Whether the lease of the quota was for the purpose of delivering milk produced by the enterprise.
d. If quota was not required, whether the legal owner of land on which a milking shed was situated leased the land.
e. Whether the land was leased for the purpose of delivering milk produced by the enterprise.
f. Whether the lease was still in existence at 6.30 pm on 28 September 1999.

If it is unclear whether a lease exists, but there is an arrangement in place whereby land on which a milking shed is situated is being used by someone other than the owner for the purposes of producing milk, an assessment is made of whether the arrangement has the attributes of a lease. In making this assessment, the Dairy Adjustment Authority (DAA) has regard to the terms of the arrangement as disclosed by the written agreement between the parties or other available evidence if no written agreement exists.
(2) The DAA has advised that it is unable under clause 43 of Schedule 2 to the Dairy Produce Act to disclose details in relation to particular cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 27 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) (a) Can a list be provided of meetings in which the Government and/or the department discussed the financial situation facing the South Johnstone sugar mill in far north Queensland including dates and who was present; and (b) can a copy of the department's minutes of the meetings be provided.

(3) (a) What safeguards did the Government put in place prior to lending this money to ensure that taxpayers' money would be repaid; and (b) can an outline of the terms of the financial agreement be provided.

(4) How much money was finally provided to finance South Johnstone Mill Limited; (b) when were these monies paid; (c) how much has been repaid and when did this occur; and (d) what is the Government doing to recoup outstanding monies.

(5) What action did the Government take when notified by CJ Cooper and Associates, solicitors for the Canegrowers Organisation, by facsimile on 5 July 2000 that advertising under the Cane Supply and Processing Agreement, dated 26 May 2000, had not been undertaken correctly as required under the Queensland Sugar Act 1999; and (b) what involvement did the Government have in this advertisement.

(6) As a creditor to South Johnstone Mill Limited, what involvement did the Government have in the sale of the mill to Bundaberg Sugar Limited; and (b) can a list be provided of meetings at which the sale of the South Johnstone mill was discussed, including dates and attendees.
(7) What proposals and options were considered prior to the sale of the South Johnstone sugar mill to Bundaberg Sugar.

(8) What involvement did the Government have in the March 2001 novation and amendment deed between South Johnstone Mill Limited, Canegrowers South Johnstone Mills Suppliers' Committee, South Johnstone Mill Negotiating Team and Bundaberg Sugar Limited.
(9) Is the repayment of the Government finance to South Johnstone Mill dependent on the validity of this deed.
(10) Can copies of any advice, legal or other, received in relation to this deed be provided.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) to (10) The Australian Government Solicitor's office has advised that those matters are the subject of current legal proceedings and as such cannot be answered. The sub-judice convention should be observed, particularly as many of the questions relate to documents which are central to issues that are before the Supreme Court in this case.
